title: 8Â  Welcome
text:
8.1 Who is this guide for?
Welcome to the Intro to Git guide! We hope this guide will be a resource for you to learn the basics of working with version control for the first time.
This guide is for students who know some R and want to learn Git and GitHub to manage and collaborate on R projects (especially Quarto ones). It assumes little-to-no hands-on terminal experience but will encourage building confidence over time by interacting with Github through the command line.
Students who are brand new to the terminal may also find it helpful to go through the Intro to Terminal section of this book before working through this guide.

title: 8Â  Welcome
text:
8.2 Prerequisites
Before we move on to working with Git and Github, we need to make sure you have what you need to successfully complete the exercises in this guide. The guide assumes you already have the following installed on your computer:

R
RStudio
Quarto

If you are missing any these, please go to the links listed and make sure to install before moving on to the next chapter!

title: 1Â  Welcome and launch
text:
1.1 What is the Terminal, Anyway?
First things first:
If youâ€™ve never opened a Terminal window before, youâ€™re not alone. This guide is here to show you that the command line isnâ€™t something to fear. Itâ€™s just a different way to tell your computer what to do â€” directly, and often much faster.
You donâ€™t need to memorize anything right now. You donâ€™t need to be a â€œtech wizard.â€ You just need a little curiosity.
A few important things before you get started:
Time to enter the Matrix, Neo.
Think of using the Terminal like dmâ€™ing your computer.
Instead of clicking buttons or opening folders with a mouse or trackpad, you type commands in the command line asking your computer to do these things for you. Your computer reads your message and replies by immediately doing what you ask.
The Terminal (on Mac) or Git Bash (on Windows) are programs that can run a shell, are just the names of the user interfaces where you will type these commands.
The Terminal might look a little old-school (and letâ€™s be real: a bit scary ğŸ‘»), but itâ€™s still one of the most powerful tools you can learn. People who work in code, data, security, and tech use it all the time.
Hereâ€™s just a few examples of what we can ask our computers to do using the Terminal:
We can do all of these things by typing just a few words. But to communicate effectively with our Terminals, we have to learn â€œspeakâ€ its language. In this guide, youâ€™ll learn the basics of this language to get you started.

title: 1Â  Welcome and launch
text:
Terminology note



People (including the authors of this guide) will use the term shell and terminal and command line interchangeably. This means when we say â€œtype into your shellâ€, â€œin your command lineâ€, or â€œin your terminalâ€, we mean type at the prompt in your Terminal or Git Bash program. Later, weâ€™ll use our Terminal from within Visual Studio Code.
In reality, there are some nuances:

The terminal opens a window.
Inside that, a shell runs.
You interact with it through the command line interface.

In practical terms, just know they usually mean the same thing out in the wild.





List all the files in a folder
Create a new folder
Install programs
Move files around
Automate tasks

title: 1Â  Welcome and launch
text:
1.2 Speaking the Terminalâ€™s language
The programming language we will use for our interactions in the Terminal is called Bash. Bash is a Unix-based program and most of the Internet runs on Unix (or Linux) computers.
Macs understand Bash natively, but Windows doesnâ€™t understand Bash at all without the help of another program. This is why Git and Git Bash were downloaded in the prerequisites â€“ so we can all speak the same language, regardless of the machines weâ€™re using.

title: 1Â  Welcome and launch
text:
1.3 How to Open the Terminal
First things first, we need to actually open the Terminal on our machines.
Hereâ€™s how to find it on your computer:

Mac:
Press Command + Space, type Terminal, and hit Enter.
Windows:
Open the Start Menu, search for Terminal or PowerShell, and open it.
(Thereâ€™s also something called â€œCommand Promptâ€ â€” close enough for now.)
Linux:
Press Ctrl + Alt + T â€” itâ€™s probably already installed!

Tip: If you want, you can change the Terminalâ€™s color theme to make it more comfortable to look at. (Weâ€™ll cover this later.)

title: 1Â  Welcome and launch
section: 1.4 Your First Command: Saying Hello to the Terminal
text:
1.4 Your First Command: Saying Hello to the Terminal
Ok, now that the Terminal is open on your computer, letâ€™s take a quick look at the text showing in the window when you launch to familiarize ourselves with basics of the interface.






Note for newer Mac users



When you launch the Terminal for the first time, youâ€™ll probably see a prompt saying something like:
The default interactive shell is now zsh.
To update your account to use zsh, please run `chsh -s /bin/zsh`.
DISREGARD THIS MESSAGE. Do not run this the command to update to zsh. Zsh is a similar language that Mac is transitioning to by default. However, we will use Bash for this guide to keep everyone on the same page, regardless of their operating systems.





When you launch Terminal for the first time, youâ€™ll see some text like this.


Letâ€™s breakdown a few things from the screenshot above:

Computer name: the characters before the ~ are your computer name.
Current directory: The ~ character is Terminal shorthand for your â€œbaseâ€ directory on your computer. The value shown here will update as you move around to different folders on your computer.
User name: The part immediatetely after the ~ is your username.
Command prompt: Lastly we have the $. This is the â€œpromptâ€ where you type commands.

You type your commands AFTER the $ and then hit Return/Enter on your keyboard to run or execute them. Weâ€™ll practice doing just that in the next section.

1.4.1 Your First Command: Saying Hello to the Terminal
Letâ€™s try your first real command: finding out where you are using the command pwd.
In the Terminal prompt (remember after the $), type the following command:
pwd
Then press Enter to run the command.
You should see Terminal respond with something like this:
/Users/yourname
or this
C:\Users\yourname
Depending on your system, the path may look a little different â€” and thatâ€™s OK.
So what just happened?

pwd stands for â€œprint working directory.â€
It simply asks: Where am I right now in the computerâ€™s folder system?
Your computer provides the answer: your current folder â€” usually your â€œhomeâ€ directory when you first open the Terminal.

title: 1Â  Welcome and launch
text:
1.5 ğŸ¯ Checkpoint
Youâ€™ve made it to the end of chapter 1. Good job!
Youâ€™ve now:

Opened the Terminal.
Typed and ran your first command.
Seen your computer respond back.

Youâ€™re officially no longer a Terminal beginner. ğŸ™Œ
A few quick Tips Before You Move On to the next chapter:

Command Case Matters in the Terminal: pwd is not the same as PWD.
Press Enter: Every command you type needs an Enter to run.
You canâ€™t break things easily: Typing pwd wonâ€™t hurt your computer.
(In fact, almost everything weâ€™ll do in this guide will be safe.)


Next up:
Weâ€™ll learn how to move around inside your computer using simple commands. Whenever youâ€™re ready, proceed to the next chapter.

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.1 Whatâ€™s in This Folder? (ls)
Now that you know where you are (pwd), itâ€™s time to explore whatâ€™s around you. Specifically, weâ€™ll start by moving between different folders on your computer.
If you want to see whatâ€™s inside the current directory, you use the ls command.
As we said in Chapter 1, the Terminal lets you interact with files the same way you would with File Explorer on Windows and Finder on a Mac â€” except youâ€™ll be using text instead of clicking.
When your first launch terminal, youâ€™ll see a ~ (called a tilde), which lets you know youâ€™re in your base or home directory. We want to ask the Terminal to tell us what is inside this home directory.
To do that, type the following command:
and press Enter to run the command.
Terminal will respond to your command with a list of files and folders like this:
Or it might be different depending on whatâ€™s in your computerâ€™s home folder.
In any case, the list of directories returned by Terminal will match the folders you would see if you clicked on your home directory in the Finder on a Mac or in File Explorer on a Windows machine. For example, the list of folders listed in the example response above matches what we see in our home directory using Finder below.
Quick Recap: What does ls stand for?

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
ls


_projects Desktop       Downloads   Movies      Pictures

Itâ€™s short for â€œlist.â€
It literally says, â€œList whatâ€™s here.â€
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.2 Moving Around (cd)
Seeing whatâ€™s around is nice â€” but what if you want to go into one of those folders?
Use the cd command, shorthand for â€œchange directoryâ€.
Suppose you see a folder called Documents.
To do so, type the following command in your Terminal:
cd Documents
and press Enter.
Now youâ€™re inside the Documents directory!
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
section: 2.3 How Can You Tell Where You Are Now? (pwd)
text:
2.3 How Can You Tell Where You Are Now? (pwd)
There are a couple ways to make sure you are where you think you are in the Terminal.
The first is to look at the command prompt line inside your Terminal window again. You should see something like:
Anas-MacBook-Air:Documents ana$
In the current directory space (where there used to be a ~), you should now see the name of the Documents folder. Remember if youâ€™re ever unsure where you are, Terminal will tell you in the prompt!
If youâ€™re still not sure, remember you can use your new friend the pwd command from Chapter 1 by typing:
pwd
Terminal should now show something like:
/Users/yourname/Documents
or
C:\Users\yourname\Documents
Nice job â€” you just moved between directories!
Now letâ€™s try sending the ls command again by typing:
ls
and hitting Enter.
You should see a different list of files and/or folder names that you did when you ran the same command inside the home directory â€” now showing the contents of your Documents folder.
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.4 Going Back Up (cd ..)
Ok now that weâ€™ve moved into folders, what if you want to go back to the folder you came from?
To go back up, type and run the following command:
cd ..
The two dots .. simply mean â€œthe folder above this one.â€
If you run the pwd command again, youâ€™ll see youâ€™re back to where you started!
crumbs: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
text:
2.5 Extra: Special Shortcuts
Here are a few handy shortcuts youâ€™ll want to remember:



Command
What it does




cd
Go back to your home directory.

Move up one directory.


cd foldername
Move into a folder.




Tip: If the folder name has spaces (like My Documents), put it in quotes:
cd "My Documents"

Or use a backslash to â€œescapeâ€ the space:
cd My\ Documents
Like we mentioned before, Terminal is particular about the way you speak to it. For it to understand you, youâ€™ve got to speak its language. But this is another reason why naming your files and directories cleanly using a naming convention like snake_case or kebab-case will help you work more efficiently.

title: 2Â  Moving Around in the Terminal
section: 2.7 ğŸ”¥ Pro Tip: Speed Up with Tab Completion
text:
2.7 ğŸ”¥ Pro Tip: Speed Up with Tab Completion
Ok, now that youâ€™ve got some practice typing things into Terminal, weâ€™ll let you in on a big time-saver: when you start typing a folder name, you donâ€™t have to type the whole thing.
Hit the Tab key after typing part of your folder name and the Terminal will try to auto-complete it for you.
See it for yourself by typing:

If thereâ€™s a Documents folder, Terminal will fill in the rest automatically!

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.1 Creating a Folder (mkdir)
Now that you can move around the Terminal like a pro, itâ€™s time to create your own stuff.
In this chapter, weâ€™ll learn to make new folders and files. Weâ€™ll also learn how to move or delete them.
Letâ€™s say you wanted to make a brand new folder on your computer. If you were doing this in Finder, youâ€™d do something like right click and hit New Folder, then youâ€™d need to fill out your folder name in the prompt next to the new folder.
To do this from the command line, we do all of this in a single prompt using the mkdir command.
If you ran the following command (donâ€™t do this):
This would create a folder called my_new_folder inside whatever directory youâ€™re inside in the Terminal.

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
mkdir stands for make directory.


mkdir my_new_folder


3.1.1 ğŸ“ Mini excercise: make a directory
Now, try the mkdir command out on your own by making a new directory inside your home directory (~).

Check youâ€™re in your home directory (Hint: you can get back to your home directory by running cd)
Type and run: mkdir terminal_practice in your command prompt
Run the ls command to make sure it worked, You should see your new directory listed in the Terminal response.

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.2 Creating a File (touch)
Like folders, we can also make new files from the command line using the touch command.

Unlike other commands weâ€™ve learned, touch isnâ€™t shorthand for anything. Itâ€™s just the name of the command to make a new, empty file in Bash ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

For example, if you ran the following command:
touch example.txt
This creates a new, empty file called example.txt.

Note: Windows users may need to use:


bash echo.> emample.txt
or bash New-Item example.txt
(Depending on if youâ€™re using PowerShell.)


3.2.1 ğŸ“ Mini excercise: make a file
Now, try the touch command on your own by making a new file inside your new terminal_practice folder.

Move into your new folder: run the command cd terminal_practice to move into your new folder.
Make a new file: Type and run the command touch terminal-file.txt.
Check your work: Run the ls command to list the files in your folder. You should see a single file listed in the Terminal response called terminal-file.txt.

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.3 Copying Files and Folders (cp)
We can also make duplicate files or folders from command line using the cp command.

cp is shorthand for â€œcopyâ€

Syntax of the cp command
cp source_file_folder destination_file_folder
The cp command takes at least two arguments in its arguments:

Source file or folder: the file or folder you want to copy
Destination file or folder: the name youâ€™d like the copy of the file or folder to be called

Try running the following inside your terminal_practice folder:
cp notes.txt copy_of_notes.txt
If you run ls again, you should now you have two files: the original (notes.txt) and the new copy (copy_of_notes.txt).
As we said before, the cp command can also copy whole directories. However, itâ€™s a little more nuanced. If youâ€™d like to learn more about copying folders, please see appendix XXX.
ğŸ“ A note about destination folders: Bash will check to see if the folder you gave it already exists. If it doesnâ€™t, Bash will create the new folder for you and place the file inside of it.

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.4 Moving or Renaming Files (mv)**
Moving files or folders from command line is also easy using the mv command. The command can also by used to rename files, depending on the syntax you use.

mv is shorthand for â€œmoveâ€

Syntax of the mv command
To move a fileâ€™s location, use the following syntax:
mv source_file destination_folder
If you just want to rename a file, use the following syntax:
mv oldname.txt newname.txt
Weâ€™ll practice the two ways to use the mv command in the next exercise.

3.4.1 ğŸ“ Mini exercise: move and rename a file
Part 1: move a file

Make new subdirectory: run the command mkdir my_new_folder to make a new folder in your terminal_practice directory.
Peek at our files: run ls to look at the files inside your terminal_practice folder to make sure the new folder is there.
Move your notes.txt file: Move the copy of your notes files into the new sub-folder in your directory by running the following command: mv copy_of_notes.txt my_new_folder/
Check that it worked: run ls to look at the files inside your terminal_practice folder. You should still see a new folder called `my_new_folder but you should not see the copy of your notes file.
Locate your notes copy file: run cd my_new_folder to move into your new folder. Then run ls to peek at the files. You should see your copy of the notes file listed.

Part 2: rename a file

Rename your notes copy file: From inside your new folder, rename the copy of your notes file by running the following command: mv copy_of_notes.txt notes_new.txt
Check that it worked: run ls to look at your files. You should see the copy of your notes files, but now with a new name

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.5 Deleting Files and Folders (rm)
You can also use the command line to delete files and folders on your machine using the rm command.

rm is shorthand for â€œremoveâ€

This command does require some caution because when you delete something from the Terminal, it doesnâ€™t go to the Trash â€” itâ€™s gone.
Syntax of the rm command:
Deleting a single file:
rm name_file_to_delete
Deleting a folder (and everything inside it):
rm -r folder_to_delete
ğŸ“ Note: The -r here is called a flag. It stands for â€œrecursiveâ€ â€” it tells rm to delete not just the folder, but also anything inside it. Weâ€™ll talk a little more about flags in the next section.

title: 3Â  Making and managing folder
text:
3.6 Quick Note About Flags ğŸ³ï¸
Flags are extra options you can add to commands to change how they behave.

Theyâ€™re usually a dash plus one or two letters. (Example: -r means â€œrecursiveâ€ for rm)
You can combine flags too (like -rf for rm -r -f, meaning â€œrecursiveâ€ and â€œforce deleteâ€).

Youâ€™ll see flags often out in the wild. As you use the command line more, youâ€™ll start to use more of these flags in your workflow to give you more control over what your commands do. For now, just know when you see something starting with a dash, itâ€™s probably a flag to add a little extra to the primary command.
Optional exercise:
If you want, try one out yourself now by using the -l flag along with the ls command.The flag tells the command line, â€œgive me more information about each file in my directoryâ€.
Run the following command:
ls -l 
Terminal will respond with detailed information about each file and folder in your directory. See the screenshot below for more information about each detail field.



Breakdown of each file detail in the -l flag Terminal response

title: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
4.1 Command History
In this brief chapter, weâ€™ll touch on a few things that should help you work quicker in the Terminal. Weâ€™ll also touch on navigating common issues youâ€™ll probably run into.
The command line keeps a history of the commands you give it. Much like scrolling back up through the messages in a conversation on your phone, you can â€œscroll upâ€ through the conversation youâ€™ve had with the Terminal (only withe Terminal, youâ€™ll only see the messages you sent).
How to view your command history:
To see prior commands youâ€™ve written, just press the up arrow â†‘ on your keyboard. Each press will take you to the prior command in your history.
To get back to an empty prompt, scroll back down using the down arrow â†“
You can re-run any command that pops up simply by hitting the Enter / return key on your keyboard. No need to re-type things!
Why this is useful
In programming, we often repeat commands quite frequently (think about how often you re-run your notebook code in R-Studio, for example).
Having a command history is helpful because it:
crumbs: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks

title: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
Saves time â€“ You can quickly repeat or modify previous commands with the â†‘ key instead of retyping them.
Reduces mistakes â€“ Reusing known-good commands lowers the chance of typos or syntax errors.
Aids learning â€“ You can review what youâ€™ve done, which helps you remember your steps and can help with troubleshooting if something goes wrong.
crumbs: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks

title: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
4.2 Canceling a Command
One of the scariest things for new Terminal users happens when you run something you didnâ€™t mean to.
If you realize you made a mistake while a command is running, press:
Ctrl + C
This cancels the running command and brings you back to the prompt.
crumbs: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks

title: 4Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
4.3 Tab Completion
You read about this in Chapter 2, but itâ€™s worth mentioning again because itâ€™s that good.
Remember: start typing a folder or file name, press Tab, and Terminal finishes it for you if possible.
Saves time and typos!
If thereâ€™s more than one similarly-named files in your folder, you may have to type more characters to get to the one you want.

title: 5Â  Troubleshooting
text:
5.1 Common pitfalls and errors
In this final chapter, letâ€™s touch quickly on navigating common issues you might run into using the Terminal.
Hereâ€™s a quick rundown of the most common problems and errors youâ€™ll run into using the command line. Even experienced developers run into these issues, so learning what they mean will go a long way when troubleshooting.
For more common issues and how to fix them, see the common errors table in the Glossary at the end of this guide.

title: 5Â  Troubleshooting
text:
Command not found? You might have a typo or the program isnâ€™t installed.
No such file or directory? Youâ€™re trying to access a file/path that doesnâ€™t exist. Check that the file exists and that your spelled it correctly.
Permission denied?
You tried to do something you donâ€™t have permission to do. Check your file/repo permissions.
Syntax error
You typed a command in a way the shell doesnâ€™t understand. Check that your syntax is correct and error-free.
Stuck in a weird app inside Terminal?
Try pressing Ctrl + C or Ctrl + D to exit.

title: 5Â  Troubleshooting
section: 5.2 How to Get Out of Vim
text:
5.2 How to Get Out of Vim
Every new command line user shares one panic-inducing experience at one point or another: accidentally opening Vim and not knowing how to get out of it.
In this section, weâ€™ll briefly walk you through what Vim is and how to exit it so you donâ€™t panic when this (inevitably) happens to you.
What is Vim?
Vim is a text editor built into most Unix systems, including macOS and Linux. Itâ€™s used by developers to edit code and configuration files, but it works very differently from regular text editors.
If you accidentally open something in Vim (for example, by running git commit without a message), it might look like youâ€™re stuck. But donâ€™t worry â€” hereâ€™s how to exit safely.
How to Exit Vim
If you donâ€™t want to save any changes - most common:

Press Esc (to make sure youâ€™re not in input mode)
Type :q! (to â€œquit and ignore changesâ€)
Hit Enter / return (to exit)

If You do want to save changes - less common:

Press Esc
Type :wq (to â€œwrite and quitâ€).
Press Enter / return

title: 10Â  Introduction to version control
text:
10.1 Introduction to Version control
Version control is a system that helps you track and manage changes to files over time. It lets you save different versions of your work, go back to earlier versions if you make a mistake, and work with other people without overwriting each otherâ€™s changes.
So what does this look like in practice?
Letâ€™s imagine for a moment that youâ€™re writing a paper. Every time you make a big edit, you save a new copy: paper_v1.docx, paper_v2.docx, paper_final.docx, etc.
Itâ€™s easy to see how it could become difficult to keep track of which version was which using this kind of a system. Now, imagine how much messier and unwieldy it could become trying to keep track of different versions of an R project with changes in multiple .qmd files AND with multiple people making edits to those files â¡ï¸ enter version control.
Version control keeps track of these different versions for you so you donâ€™t have to. Have you ever used the versions feature in Google docs when working on an article draft? Then youâ€™ve interacted with a type of version control.

title: 9Â  Introduction to version control
text:
Track changes you make to your project files.
Save â€œsnapshotsâ€ (called commits) of your project over time.
Go back to an earlier snapshot if needed.
See what exactly changed between versions.
Work with teammates without messing up each othersâ€™ work.







Store your Git project safely in the cloud.
Share your project with others.
Collaborate with other people (even if they are far away).
Keep a backup in case your computer crashes.




Version control: Describes the system of tracking changes to your files over time so you can revisit or undo edits, collaborate with others, and keep a history of your work.
Git: a version control tool you use on your computer to track changes.
GitHub: a website where you can upload (and share) your Git projects.

title: 11Â  Installation and setup
text:
11.1 Install the Tools
Before we can get started, weâ€™ll need to make sure that our computers (often referred to as our local machines) are have the tools we need. Letâ€™s do that by completing the following steps:

title: 11Â  Installation and setup
text:
Install Git

Go to: https://git-scm.com/downloads
Download and install Git
Default install settings are fine

Sign up for a Github account:

Go to: https://github.com
Click Sign up
Fill in your email and password
Choose a username. Keep this professional enough that you wouldnâ€™t mind a professor, colleague or future employer seeing it.







Caution



Remember, the username you set here will be visible (read: public) in any future projects you push to GitHub. If you choose to use a nickname or alias instead of your real name, keep it professional enough that you wouldnâ€™t mind future colleagues or a potential employer seeing it if needed to share your work.

title: 11Â  Installation and setup
text:
11.2 Configure Git
After installing Git, youâ€™ll need to go through a one-time process to configure it with your username and email on your computer. Weâ€™ll use the terminal to do this.
Step 1: Start a new terminal session in RStudio

Launch R Studio
Click on the terminal tab to start a new session (if there isnâ€™t one already).


Tip: The terminal tab is located next to the Console tab. If canâ€™t find the terminal tab, go to Tools > Terminal > Move Focus to Terminal .

Step 2: Set your Git username
First, weâ€™ll set your user.name so Git knows who you are. The username you set here will be associated with future commits to your projects which may be public, so this name should also be professional enough that you wouldnâ€™t mind a future employee seeing it. We recommend using your first name and last name.

Run the following command from your terminal, replacing â€œYour Nameâ€ with your name (including the quotation marks):
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
Check to see if you successfully set your name by running the command:
git config user.name

You should see a terminal response with the username you entered.
If you didnâ€™t get the response expected, then try again. Remember, be careful about punctuation.
Step 3: Setting your git email
Now weâ€™ll set your user.email.
The email you enter needs to match the one you used to setup your Github account. If it doesnâ€™t, youâ€™ll run into permissions issues later.

In your terminal, type and run the following command, but replace the email with your email (including the quotation marks):
git config --global user.email "email@example.com"







Important



Your git email should be the same as the one you use on GitHub so your commits will be linked correctly. If it doesnâ€™t match, you may run into permissions issues later on.


Step 4: Set your default branch
Next, weâ€™ll set git to name your default branch â€œmainâ€ instead of â€œmasterâ€ as this is a new standard.

In your terminal, run this:
git config --global init.defaultBranch main

You wonâ€™t get a response unless there was a problem.
Step 5: Ensure a clean git history
Lastly, weâ€™ll set a preferred Git configuration for our UT-Data projects. While the exact behavior is a bit complex, this setting helps keep our commit history clean and is recommended in this detailed explanation.

In your terminal, run this:
git config --global pull.ff only

title: 10Â  Installation and setup
text:
10.3 Setup your SSH Keys
There are a couple of ways to authenticate with Github from your computer. The book Happy Git with R recommends using personal access tokens and I think that is fine, but I prefer the one-and-done nature of SSH keys, so that is the method we will use.

After making sure git is installed, launch RStudio. (If it was already open, quit and re-launch it.)
Go to the menu Tools > Global Options, then click on the Git/SVN tab.
Check the Enable version control interface for RStudio button.
There should already be a path included in the Make sure the path to the git executable is correct.

If it is not, try quitting RStudio and relaunching it and do this step again.
If it is still not there, talk to the prof. Weâ€™ll find it.





Git/SVN window



10.3.1 Create a new SSH key
If you SSH Key path was already filled then you can skip to the next step.
If youâ€™ve never used SSH keys before, youâ€™ll have to create one, but RStudio makes that fairly painless.

Click on the Create RSA Key button.
You should be able to leave all the defaults as they are. Leave the optional Passphrase field blank.
Click Create.
You should see a message that says â€œKey Created Successfullyâ€ and it might show you a pretty picture. Click OK.




SSH Key Creation window

title: 11Â  Installation and setup
text:
11.4 Add SSH key in Github
Finally, weâ€™ll save part of the contents (the public key) of that key in your Github account. This is so Github â€œknowsâ€ about your computer.
To access your â€œPublicâ€ key, do the following:

In the RStudio Git/SVN window, click on the View public key button.
This will open a new window with the contents of your public key.
Copy the full contents of the public key.

Weâ€™ll paste the contents of this key into Github in the next steps.



Public key example


Add the public key to Github by doing the following:

Go to github.com, choose Settings in the dropdown under your User Profile photo.
In the user settings sidebar on the left, click SSH and GPG keys.
Click New SSH key or Add SSH key.
In the â€œTitleâ€ field, add a descriptive label for the new key. Name it something like â€œPersonal MacBook Airâ€ to indicate its your personal computer.
In the â€œKeyâ€ field, paste ( Command+V)the public key you copied from RStudio into the box.
It will look something like this:



Saving the key


Click Add SSH key.
If prompted, confirm your GitHub password.


11.4.1 Test Github connection
Letâ€™s make sure everything is hooked up correctly between our local machine and remote Github account.
In RStudio, do the following:
Step 1: Restart Terminal

Go to the Terminal pane in RStudio.
Click the small carrot (â–¾) in your terminal tab.
Select New Terminal in the dropdown to launch a new Terminal.

Step 2: Test Gitub connection

Run the following from your new Terminal tab:
ssh -T git@github.com
If you are asked about â€œRSA key fingerprintâ€, type yes and hit Enter / return.

In the end, you should have a success message like: â€œHi username! Youâ€™ve successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.â€
If you get that message, you are good to move on!

title: 11Â  Installation and setup
text:
11.5 ğŸ¯ Checkpoint
Ok, we covered a lot in this section.
In this chapter you:

Downloaded Git.
Setup your Github account.
Set your Git username (with an appropriate name or alias).
Set your Git email (using the email on your account Github account).
Setup SSH Keys to authenticate with Github.

Now that Git is configured, youâ€™re ready to create your first project. ğŸ‰

Next up
In the next chapter, weâ€™ll walk you through creating a new Quarto project with Git tracking from the start using the terminal.

title: 12Â  Make a Git project
text:
12.1 Create a new RStudio Project
Before we can add anything to our Github, we need a Quarto project to track.
Follow the steps below to make a new Quarto project in RStudio:
Make a new Quarto project
In RStudio, navigate to:
In the â€œCreate Quarto Websiteâ€ window, do the following:
Youâ€™ll now have a project with some base project files, inclued an index.qmd file.

title: 12Â  Make a Git project
text:
File â†’ New Project â†’ New Directory â†’ Quarto Website



Give your directory a descriptive name like my-first-git-project in the Directory Name field.
Check the Create project as a subdirectory of field to make sure youâ€™re creating your project in the folder where you keep your class or coding projects on your computer.
Make sure none of the boxes are checked.
Finally, click Create Project.

title: 12Â  Make a Git project
text:
12.2 Run a Quarto File
Before we get into Git, letâ€™s quickly make sure Quarto is working as expected by rendering one of our new files.

In the Files pane, find your index.qmd file and click to open it.
Change the title to something like â€œIntro to Gitâ€.
Click the â¡ï¸ Render button in the top toolbar.

A new browser window should open with an HTML preview of your file.
Great! Youâ€™re ready to start version-controlling this project.

title: 12Â  Make a Git project
text:
12.3 Initialize Git in our Project
If we want Git to start watching our files and keeping track of our changes, we have to make sure Git is connected to our project. To do this, we need to initialize Git inside of our Quarto project.
In basic terms, initializing tells Git â€œI want you to start tracking this folder.â€
To initialize git, do the following:

Navigate to the Terminal tab inside the Console pane in RStudio.
In the terminal, run this:
git init

If it works, youâ€™ll see Terminal respond with something like:
Initialized empty Git repository in /Users/yourname/my-quarto-project/.git/
Whatâ€™s actually happening here?
This command creates a hidden folder called .git inside the project folder. This folder contains all the information Git needs to track changes in our project.

title: 12Â  Make a Git project
section: 12.4 Ask Git what it sees (git status)
text:
12.4 Ask Git what it sees (git status)
Now that weâ€™ve let Git know that we want it to start watching our project by initializing, we can ask Git what it â€œseesâ€ using the git status command.
Letâ€™s try this out now

Run the following command

git status
Terminal will return something like the following as a response:
On branch main

No commits yet

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
        .Rproj.user/
        .quarto/
        _quarto.yml
        my-first-git-project.Rproj
        my-first-git-project.html
        my-first-git-project.qmd
        my-first-git-project_files/

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
Letâ€™s quickly breakdown what this all means:

â€œOn branch mainâ€: Youâ€™re working on the main branch â€” the default starting branch for development.
â€œNo commits yetâ€: This means Git is ready, but you havenâ€™t saved any versions yet.
â€œUntracked Filesâ€: These are files Git sees in your folder, but itâ€™s not saving changes to them yet. These files are marked in red in the terminal.

The git status command will be used frequently throughout this guide, and you should use it a lot in your own Git workflow. Itâ€™s an incredibly helpful command for tracking your progress and helping you to make sure you are where you think you are.

title: 12Â  Make a Git project
text:
12.5 ğŸ¯ Checkpoint
In this chapter youâ€™ve:

Made a new Quarto project and rendered your index file.
Initialized Git inside your project (git init).
Learned how to ask Git about the status of our project files (git status).


Next up
In the next step, weâ€™ll learn how to tell Git what files weâ€™d like it to track and which files to ignore. Then weâ€™ll take our first â€œsnapshotâ€ of our project. Proceed when youâ€™re ready!

title: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
text:
13.1 Ignoring files
In our last chapter, we ran the git status command to tell us what Git sees within our project.
Letâ€™s take another look at those files.
Under the â€œuntracked filesâ€ sections, you should see a list of files in red like:
Currently, Git â€œseesâ€ all the files in your working directory, including some files we may not actually want to include.
For example, notice those .html files in the list? HTML files are the rendered output from Quarto, and they change every time you make a change and click â€œRenderâ€ â€“ something we tend to do a lot in our Quarto files.
Generally-speaking, we donâ€™t save these kinds of rendered files in our repositories because they change so frequently and can cause a lot of headaches down the line, especially if weâ€™re working with other people.
That said, there are some notable exceptions when you might include these files in Github:
For our purposes, weâ€™ll be following the general best practice of excluding these kinds of rendered files â€“ weâ€™ll walk through how to do that below.
crumbs: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files

title: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
text:
Run the following:
git status


        .Rproj.user/
        .quarto/
        _quarto.yml
        my-first-git-project.Rproj
        my-first-git-project.html
        my-first-git-project.qmd
        my-first-git-project_files/





If theyâ€™re small, essential, and need to be versioned for a specific reason.
If youâ€™re outputting human-readable deliverables (like a PDF report or documentation site).
If youâ€™re working on a static site or book.
crumbs: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files

title: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
text:
13.2 Introducing .gitignore
In a Git project, there are several types of files and directories that you typically want to keep out of our repositories to keep things clean, secure, and easy to manage.
What you ignore will depend on the type of project and the coding languages youâ€™re using, but all Github projects use a file called .gitignore to let Git know what it shouldnâ€™t be tracking in the project.
In general, the following kinds of files shouldnâ€™t be tracked in Github:

Sensitive files: Files containing passwords or private information
Big files: Git isnâ€™t built to keep track of large files.

For R and Quarto projects, this will include the following common file types:

Session and history files: .Rhistory, .RData, .Rproj.user/
Knitting files: .utf8.md, .knit.md
Output/render folders: *_files/ ,_site/, _book/
Editor and IDE Config Files: .Rproj.user/

Donâ€™t worry if you donâ€™t fully understand what all of these files are yet. The important thing here is to know is that there are things we should and should not upload to Github, and the way we keep the things we donâ€™t want tracked out of our Github project is by using a .gitignore file.
Weâ€™ll set one up for our new project in the next step.
crumbs: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files

title: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
text:
13.3 ğŸ“ Exercise: make a .gitignore
Letâ€™s make a .gitignore file for your new Git project using the command line and the touch command.

In the terminal, run:
touch .gitignore
In the RStudio Files pane, click on the new .gitignore file to open it.

Tip: If you donâ€™t see the .gitignore in your file pane, you may need to refresh by clicking the refresh icon at the top right of the file pane.

In your blank .gitignore file, add the following lines and save the file:
*.html 
_site/ 
.Rproj.user/
Check your Git status again by running:
git status

Remember when we ran git status before and we saw those .html files in our list of untracked files? Now the .html files should be gone from the list of files Git â€œseesâ€ because weâ€™ve told it to ignore these types of files with the *.html line in our ignore file.
Letâ€™s quickly break down what each of these mean:

*.html : Ignore all .html files. (The * here tells Git â€œall files ending in .htmlâ€, regardless of their names)
_site/: Ignore the entire contents of the _site folder.
.Rproj.user/: Ignore the hidden RStudio files in the `.Rproj.user/ folder.

Before moving forward, letâ€™s add a few more things to the .gitignore to cover some additional things we want to ignore (donâ€™t worry about understanding what all of these are right now).

Copy and paste the following code into your .gitignore file:
# R
.Rhistory
.RData
.Rproj.user/

# Quarto
*.html
*_files/
*.utf8.md
*.knit.md
_site/
_book/

# System
.DS_Store
Save and close the file.
Run git status to preview the files git sees after the changes.
crumbs: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files

title: 12Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
section: 12.4 Staging: Adding the files you do want
text:
12.4 Staging: Adding the files you do want
Now that weâ€™ve told Git what we donâ€™t want to keep track of, we need to tell Git to track the rest of our files. Weâ€™ll do that by using the add command.
Type the run the following command in your terminal:
git add .
The . after the add means â€œadd everything in this folderâ€ (ignoring anything listed in .gitignore.)
Run git status again
The output should look something like this now:
On branch main

No commits yet

Changes to be committed:
  (use "git rm --cached <file>..." to unstage)
        new file:   .gitignore
        new file:   _quarto.yml
        new file:   my-git-quarto-project.Rproj
        new file:   my-git-quarto-project.qmd
Notice that the heading has changed to â€œChanges to be committedâ€ and files are now shown in green. This is called Staging.
crumbs: 12Â  Add, ignore, and commit files

title: 12Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
text:
12.5 Committing: take your first Snapshot
Now that youâ€™ve told Git which files you care about, itâ€™s time to take a â€œsnapshotâ€ of these files.
Run the following in your command line:
git commit -m "Initial commit: set up Quarto project"
crumbs: 12Â  Add, ignore, and commit files

title: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
text:
13.6 ğŸ¯ Checkpoint
In this chapter you:

Created a .gitignore file
Added the files you wanted to track (staged your files)
Took your first project snapshot (committed your files)

Great job! Youâ€™ve saved the first version of your project locally (AKA on your computer). Now, the snapshot needs to be saved to a remote project (AKA Github).

Next up
Youâ€™ll learn how to send this â€œsnapshotâ€ of our project by pushing our changes to Github for safe keeping.
crumbs: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files

title: 14Â  Pushing to Github
text:
14.1 Create a Repository on GitHub
Now that your project changes have been committed locally on your computer, letâ€™s put it on GitHub so you can back it up and collaborate with others.
First things first, we need to actually make a place for our project on Github. In Github, this is called a repository. Think of a repository (or repo for short) like making a new folder in Google Drive where youâ€™d save all your interview notes, research and drafts when working on a story.
To make new Github repository:
This URL is the â€œaddressâ€ where your repository lives. Weâ€™ll use it to connect our local Git project to our Github project in the next step.

title: 14Â  Pushing to Github
text:
Go to github.com and log in.
Click the + in toolbar at the upper right corner. Then click â€œNew repositoryâ€ in the dropdown.
Do the following in the Create a new repository form:

Fill in the Repository name field, using the same name as your project folder (e.g.Â my-quarto-project)
Leave Description blank for now
Leave the box unchecked that says â€œInitialize this repository with a READMEâ€ (We can add this on our own later)
Leave the other defaults as-is (None gitignore and None for licence)

Click Create repository.
Youâ€™ll now see a page with instructions on how to connect your local folder to this GitHub repository.
In the Quick setup box

Click the SSH tab to get the correct URL to clone (it will begin with git@ instead of https:)
Click the copy icon button next to the â€œSSH URLâ€ box to copy the URL to your clipboard

title: 14Â  Pushing to Github
section: 14.2 Connect your local Git project to GitHub
text:
14.2 Connect your local Git project to GitHub
Weâ€™re now ready to hook up local project to our Github project. Weâ€™ll only have to do this once, but it involves a couple steps
First, weâ€™ll add our remote project by doing the following:

Navigate to the Terminal tab inside your RStudio Quarto project.
Type the following command, but replace the URL with the one you copied from GitHub:
git remote add origin git@github.com:your-name/your-repo-name.git
Run the command by hitting Enter / return.

Now, weâ€™ll add our saved snapshot of our files to Github by pushing our changes:

Run the following:
git push -u origin main

title: 14Â  Pushing to Github
section: 14.3 Quick Recap: what do these commands do?
text:
14.3 Quick Recap: what do these commands do?
Ok, we just did a lot there. Letâ€™s pause for a moment and breakdown everything we just did:

git remote add origin {REPO_URL}: Told Git where your online repository lives (on GitHub).
git push -u origin main
This command did two things:

Setup a link between your local main branch and the main branch on GitHub.
â€œPushedâ€ your local commits (aka the â€œsnapshotâ€ we took last section) to GitHub.


In short, these steps connected your local project to your remote project on Github, then saved the snapshot you took to the cloud. We wonâ€™t have to repeat these exact steps ever again when saving snapshots in the future for this project.
That said, is the process you will follow when making new Github projects in the future, so make sure you understand the basics of what we did here.
ğŸ‰ Congratulations: you now have your first live project is on GitHub!

title: 14Â  Pushing to Github
section: 14.4 ğŸ“ Mini exercise: explore Your GitHub project
text:
14.4 ğŸ“ Mini exercise: explore Your GitHub project
Go to your repository page on GitHub (or refresh the page if you still have it open from before).
You should see all your project files, including .qmd, .gitignore, etc.
Pay attention to whatâ€™s showing in the file list. Youâ€™ll see some helpful information about the project, including:

Which user made the most recent commit
The commit message
The commit number
The timestamp of the commit In the file list
The commit message and timestamp from the most recent update made to each file or folder.

Take a few minutes to click on some of your files and get familiar with the Github interface.






Note



Not every file will update with each git push. Git only keeps track of changes to files. If you made no edits to a file in a commit, it wonâ€™t change. Timestamps will help you track when updates were last made different parts of your project!

title: 14Â  Pushing to Github
text:
14.5 ğŸ¯ Checkpoint
At this point in the guide, youâ€™ve learned how to:

Create a new RStudio project.
Turn on Git tracking with git init.
Tell Git to ignore files (.gitignore).
Stage and commit changes to Git (git add and git commit).
Connect your local project to your remote GitHub repository (git remote add origin).
Push your first commit to Github (git push).


Next up:
Weâ€™ll learn how to make changes, track versions, and collaborate like pros.

title: 15Â  Updating files
text:
15.1 The basic git workflow
Youâ€™ll also practice writing good commit messages and checking your work.
Now that we have our local repository setup and connected to our remote repository on Github, letâ€™s briefly go over the basic Github workflow you will repeat over and over again as you work on your project.
The basic git workflow goes like this:
Some additional steps may be added if you begin using more advanced features in Git later on â€“ especially when working with a team â€“ but the basic steps outlined above will still apply even when working with more complicated workflows like feature branches and pull requests.
Weâ€™ll practice this workflow in the sections below.

title: 15Â  Updating files
text:
The basic workflow youâ€™ll repeat when working with Github.




You make changes to your local repository files.
You take a snapshot of those changes by committing them on your local repo.
You push those committed changes to Github to track.
Before making more changes, you pull down the most recent changes from Github.
Rinse and repeat.

title: 15Â  Updating files
text:
15.2 Make a small change
To see this process in action, letâ€™s make a couple changes to our project.

Open the Quarto file you made in Chapter 1 (e.g., 01-index.qmd)
Replace the auto-generated text and code blocks in the file with the following (feel free to copy/paste):
---
title: "Intro to Git"
format: html
---

# Summary

Here is a summary of the `mtcars` dataset.
Under the summary header and description, add a new code block with the following:
summary(mtcars)
Save the file.

Now that weâ€™ve made a change to our files, letâ€™s check in with Git:

Go back to your Terminal window, and run the following:
git status

The Terminal should respond with something like this:
On branch main
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/main'.

Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git restore <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
        modified:   01-index.qmd
Letâ€™s break this down:

We see the label modified: next to our filename, which tells us that Git sees that something has changed.
But, the file is under the Changes not staged for commit: section and in red font, which tells us that Git hasnâ€™t staged it yet (so it wonâ€™t be saved in the next commit).

title: 14Â  Updating files
text:
14.3 Stage the Change
Now that you know Git sees the change, you need to tell Git, â€œHey, save this file in the next snapshot.â€
Youâ€™ll do this by adding â€” or staging â€” the modified file for your next commit.
To stage your changed file, run:
git add 01-index.qmd
Now, check your Git status again.
git status
You should see your 01-index.qmd file in green, along with following message:
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git restore --staged <file>..." to unstage)
  modified:   01-index.qmd`
ğŸ‰ Great! Your changed file is now staged and ready to commit.

title: 14Â  Updating files
text:
14.4 Commit your change
Now, weâ€™ll save the snapshot of our updated file in Gitâ€™s memory. When we do so, weâ€™ll want to include a descriptive commit message noting what we changed. Git commits always need a message attached to them.
A few best practices to keep in mind with commit messages:

Use present tense: "Add summary of...", not "Added..."
Keep it short but descriptive
Think: â€œWhat changed in this version?â€, write that in the message.

âœ… Good commit messages make it easier for you and others to pick up where you left off. If something breaks during an update or if you need to go back to a prior version, commit messages will help your retrace your steps.
With those things in mind, practice writing a descriptive commit message with your change to the 01-index.qmd.
Type something like the following and hit enter:
git commit -m "Add summary of mtcars dataset"
Terminal will respond with a summary of insertions and deletions in your file.
A quick word of caution about the -m flag and Vim
Git commits always need a message attached to them. The -m flag tells the command line that weâ€™ll be writing our message inline with our command.
If you forget to include that message flag, the Terminal will open its default text editor called Vim. If you find yourself in this scenario and donâ€™t know how to get out, thereâ€™s a section on getting out of Vim in our Terminal Guide.

title: 14Â  Updating files
text:
14.5 Push your commit to GitHub
Now, that our changes are staged and commited, weâ€™ll send the snapshot from your computer to GitHub by pushing our changes.
Push your new commit by running:
git push
Now go to your repository on Github â€” youâ€™ll see your commit listed under the Commits tab and your file under the <>Codetab! (You may need to refresh)






Note



You may be wondering why this push command was shorter than it was last time. In your last push, you needed to connect local project (the one on your computer) to the remote repository on Github and set your main branch.
Since you already connected your Quarto project to Github and set our branch to main, you can just use the git push command now.

title: 15Â  Updating files
text:
15.6 Git workflow best practices
Before we move on, hereâ€™s a few key best practices to keep in mind as youâ€™re getting used to working in Git:

Commit early, commit often: Save your work frequently in small, logical chunks. This makes changes easier to track, understand, and roll back.
Stage changes selectively: Use git add <filename> (instead of git add .) when you want more control over what goes into each commit. Being surgical helps keep things clean.
Write clear commit messages: Use concise, meaningful messages that explain why the change was made. (e.g., â€œFix typo in introductionâ€, not just â€œupdateâ€)
Check status regularly: Run git status often to see whatâ€™s changed and whatâ€™s staged.

title: 15Â  Updating files
text:
15.7 ğŸ¯ Checkpoint
In this chapter, you learned the basic git workflow by:

Making a change to your local project.
Staging the changes in git (git add ..).
Taking a snapshot of the changed files (git commit -m ...).
Pushing your changes to Github (git push).

You also learned a few more best practices to keep things clean and manageable.
This is the cycle you will repeat over and over again as you work on coding projects using git.

Next up:
Weâ€™ll learn how to make changes, track versions, and collaborate like pros.

title: 15Â  Project setup and basic workflow
text:
15.1 Basic Git workflow with a team
Now that you can push your changes to GitHub, itâ€™s time to talk about how to collaborate with others on the same project.
One of the best things about using keeping your code in a Github repository is that it allows you to collaborate with other people on the same coding project. Now, to make this collaboration work smoothly, there are some best practices and processes you will need to follow.
When working in a Git project with other people, the collaboration process builds upon the basic workflow we laid out in the Updating Your Repo chapter.
Before working on your own changes in your local repo, you will pull down the most recent version of the Github project to make sure youâ€™re incorporating the most recent changes to the project. This helps you stay in sync with your team and prevents you from overwriting each othersâ€™ work and creating major conflicts later.
After grabbing the most recent version, each member of your team will then follow the basic git workflow of make changes to files on your local repositories, committing your changes, and pushing your changes to your shared remote project stored in Github.
Weâ€™ll go over the basics of setting up this kind of shared project below.
crumbs: 15Â  Project setup and basic workflow

title: 15Â  Project setup and basic workflow
section: 15.2 Setting up the shared Github project
text:
15.2 Setting up the shared Github project

15.2.1 Create the repo
Only one group member needs to create the GitHub repo (you already know howâ€”see Push the Initial Commit to GitHub).
Once the repo is created, the owner can add team members.
To add team members, the owner will:

Go to the repository on GitHub.
Click Settings â†’ Collaborators.
Add the teammateâ€™s GitHub username.


Note: This sends them an invitation. They must accept it before they can push changes.




15.2.2 Step 2: The collaborator clones the repo
Once added as a collaborator, the second person can make a copy of the repo on their machine. This process of copying a repository onto your computer is called cloning in the Git world.
Weâ€™ll walk through how to clone a repo in a moment, but first, letâ€™s make sure you know where you should clone things.

15.2.2.1 Choose where to clone the repo
Using the cd command, navigate in your terminal to the folder where you keep your coding projects. For example, a good place for this might be in a projects folder inside your home directory or your Documents folder.
If you need to create a folder for your projects, you can do this in the terminal like this:
cd ~              # Go to your home folder 
mkdir projects    # Make a folder called 'projects' (if it doesn't already exist) 
cd projects       # Move into that folder`


15.2.2.2 Clone the repo
Now that youâ€™re in the right place, youâ€™re ready to copy the repo onto your local machine following the steps below.
In Github:

Navigate to the repo you want to clone.
Click the big, blue <> CODE button (at the top right).
Navigate to the SSH tab in the dropdown.
You will see a box with something like: git@github.com:username/repository-name. Click the icon next to this box to copy it to your clipboard.

In your Terminal window, type:
git clone 
then paste the URL you copied from Github, making sure there is a space between the word â€œcloneâ€ and the URL.
Your complete command should look something like:
git clone git@github.com:username/my-first-git-repo
Hit enter to run the command.
This creates a local folder with the repoâ€™s contents and Git history within the projects folder on your computer.
Check to make sure this worked by running list (ls) command from inside the folder where you cloned your project.
ls
You should see the name of your newly-cloned repo in the list.



15.2.3 Step 3: Everyone pulls before they work
Now that you have the copy of your repo on your local machine, make sure you navigate into your project folder by running:
cd folder_name
Before making changes in the project, always run:
git pull
This downloads any changes your teammate pushed to GitHub since you last worked.

âš ï¸ Skipping git pull can lead to merge conflicts when Git sees two people changed the same thing differently.
crumbs: 15Â  Project setup and basic workflow

title: 15Â  Project setup and basic workflow
section: 15.3 Each Person Works, Commits, and Pushes
text:
15.3 Each Person Works, Commits, and Pushes
When working collaboratively on a coding project, your team will follow the basic Git workflow to keep things smooth, clean, and easy to manage.
The basic Git workflow:
You and your teammates take turns:

Making changes locally to project files
Staging and committing them (git add, git commit -m)
Pushing to GitHub (git push)

And remember, every time you go to work on your project, you and your teammates should pull before making your own edits:
git pull
crumbs: 15Â  Project setup and basic workflow

title: 17Â  Dealing with conflicts
text:
17.1 What if you both edit the same file?
Merge conflicts are an inevitable part of the collaboration process in Git. Knowing what to do when you encounter them will go a long way toward making your shared projects run smoothly.
As we covered in the last chapter, before you make changes to your project you want to pull the most recent changes from the Github repo. When you run the git pull command, Git will automatically try to merge your local changes with the most-recent version of the file on the Github repo.
In an ideal world, Git is able to merge things without any issues. But sometimes, two people (or even just you on two different branches) will make different changes to the same lines of a file.
When you try to run git pull, Git gets confused and says:
This is called a merge conflict.
When merging, Git is trying to combine the changes from two versions of a file into one. Most of the time, if the changes are in different parts of the files, Git can handle it automatically.
But if two people made edits to the same part of a file (like the same sentence or section), Git doesnâ€™t want to guess whoâ€™s right â€” so it stops and asks you to make the call.
Think of it like this:
In Git world, this is a merge conflict, and Git needs your help to resolve it.

title: 17Â  Dealing with conflicts
text:
â€œI donâ€™t know which version you want to keep â€” you have to decide.â€






Youâ€™re merging two Word documents together.
One version says â€œThe sky is blue.â€
The other version says â€œThe sky is purple.â€
Git says: â€œYou canâ€™t have both. Which one do you want?â€



17.1.1 How will Git let me know thereâ€™s a conflict?
When Git encounters a merge conflict, two things will happen:

In your Terminal, youâ€™ll see a message like:

Auto-merging filename.qmd CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in analysis.qmd Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.

In the file with the conflict, Git will mark the conflicted lines like this:
<<<<<<< HEAD This is your version. ======= This is your teammateâ€™s version. >>>>>>> abc123

Youâ€™ll need to manually choose which version (or both!) to keep and then commit the right changes to Git. Weâ€™ll walk you through the process of resolving these conflicts in the section below.

title: 17Â  Dealing with conflicts
text:
17.3 Tips for Smooth Collaboration

Communicate! Decide who is editing what and when.
Always git pull before you start working.
Commit and push frequently â€” donâ€™t wait until the end of the day.
Avoid working on the same file at the same time.


Next up
Youâ€™ll learn how to use feature branches to make collaborations smoother.

title: 18Â  Working with feature branches
text:
18.1 Why Use Branches?
In Git, a branch is like a parallel universe for your code. You can work on a new idea or fix a bug without messing up the main project. When youâ€™re ready, you bring your changes back to the main project with a merge.
Letâ€™s say youâ€™re working with teammates. One of you is writing the introduction, another is cleaning the data, and a third is building plots.
If you all worked on the main branch at the same time, youâ€™d likely constantly bump into each other â€” accidentally overwriting work or creating conflicts. Branches let everyone work on their own part of the project safely.

title: 18Â  Working with feature branches
section: 18.2 ğŸŒ± Step 1: Create a New Branch
text:
18.2 ğŸŒ± Step 1: Create a New Branch
Before we start, letâ€™s look at what branches exist in our project.

In your terminal, run the following command:
git branch

Youâ€™ll likely just see the main branch with an * symbol next to it. The asterisk tells you this is the branch you are currently working on in Git. We set this up at the start of our Git workflow.
Now, letâ€™s say you wanted to try a new chart using the ggplot library, but you werenâ€™t sure if youâ€™re ready to use this in the full project. Youâ€™d like some room to experiment a bit before fully committing your work to the main project. This is where a feature branch comes in.
Before we jump into making our first branch, letâ€™s cover some best practices when naming feature branches:

Use lowercase and hyphens (avoid spaces, underscores, or uppercase letters).
Keep names short but descriptive (include enough context to understand purpose: fix-overflow-navbar, not fix-bug).
Use consistent tense (preferably use a verb-noun format like add-navbar or fix-login-bug).

There are more conventions you would want to follow (such as using prefixes for branch types such as feature/, bugfix/, etc.) especially if working within a developer team, but for now these will be enough to get you started.
Letâ€™s try making a new branch now.

Run the following command in the terminal:
git checkout -b add-plot-experiment

You should see a response in the terminal saying something like:

Switched to a new branch â€˜add-plot-experimentâ€™

This command did two things:

checkout: Tells Git you want to switch to another branch.
-b add-plot-experiment: the -b flag tells Git that youâ€™ll be creating a new branch called add-plot-experiment. Without the flag, Git would try to switch to a branch that already existed.

Now letâ€™s confirm that youâ€™re on the new branch.

Run the branch command again:

git branch
Youâ€™ll see something like:
*add-plot-experiment
main
Remember, the * shows your current branch. So youâ€™re now on add-plot-experiment, a â€œsandboxâ€ thatâ€™s separate from your main branch in Git.

title: 18Â  Working with feature branches
section: 18.3 Step 2: make and commit changes on the new branch
text:
18.3 Step 2: make and commit changes on the new branch
Now that youâ€™re on this new feature branch (which is an exact clone of our main branch at the time it is created), we can begin to safely experiment. You can make changes to our branch without worrying about messing up the work on our main branch.
Letâ€™s try adding some new files to test this out.
In RStudio, do the following:

Make a new quarto file called 01-plot.qmd
Inside the file, make a new code block cell and add the following code:
library(tidyverse)

ggplot(mtcars, aes(x=hp, y=mpg, color=cyl)) +
    geom_point(size=3)
Run the cell to generate a simple ggplot() scatterplot.
Save the file.

Now, weâ€™ll add the new plot file to Git by completing the normal Git workflow steps:

Run git status to see whatâ€™s changed.
Type and run git add 01-plot.qmd to tell Git to start tracking your new file.
Run git status again to make sure your new file showing under â€œchanges to be committedâ€.
Run git commit -m "Add experimental plot" to take a snapshot of your changes.

This process is exactly the same as it has been for our other updates. However, this time youâ€™ve saved the snapshot of your file only to the add-plot-experiment branch, not to main.
Importantly, these changes have not been pushed to Github yet. Weâ€™ll do that next.

title: 17Â  Working with feature branches
section: 17.4 Step 3: Push the Branch to GitHub
text:
17.4 Step 3: Push the Branch to GitHub
Once youâ€™ve committed some changes on your branch, youâ€™ll probably want to back up your work by pushing it to Github.
The syntax to add a new branch to your repo is just like it was when we added our main branch:
git push -u origin branch-name
This command does two things:

Creates the new branch on GitHub
Links your local branch to it.

So if you wanted to add your new plot-experiment branch, for example, youâ€™d type and run:
git push -u origin plot-experiment
Terminal would show a response like:

To github.com:username/my-git-quarto-project.git [new branch] plot-experiment -> plot-experiment branch â€˜plot-experimentâ€™ set up to track â€˜origin/plot-experimentâ€™.*

Youâ€™ll now see the branch listed in your GitHub repo.



Github will display new feature branches in your repository

title: 18Â  Working with feature branches
text:
18.5 Merging back into main
If youâ€™re happy with your changes on your feature branch and want to add it to your main project, youâ€™ll do so by merging the changes from your feature branch back into your main branch to incorporate them into your project.
To do so, follow the steps below.
Step 1: switch back to main

Run the following to get back to your main branch:
git checkout main
Run git branch again. The asterisk should show next to main again.

Ok, now that weâ€™re on a main branch, we want to bring in the changes from add-plot-experiment.
Heads-up: if youâ€™ve still got your 01-plot.qmd file open in R Studio when you switch back to your main branch, youâ€™ll get a pop-up telling you that the plot file has been deleted (see screenshot). Thatâ€™s because the file doesnâ€™t exist yet on the main branch. Hit the blue Yes button in the pop to close the file. Donâ€™t worry though, the file still exists on your add-plot-experiment branch because you made a snapshot of your work with your git commit.ğŸ¤ 



RStudio may show a warning when switching branches


Step 2: merge the feature branch into main

Type and run:
git merge add-plot-experiment

This pulls the changes from your feature branch into the main project.
If everything goes smoothly, youâ€™ll see a message like:
Updating abc1234..def5678 Fast-forward  myfile.qmd | 10 ++++++++++  1 file changed, 10 insertions(+)

Note: If Git canâ€™t automatically combine changes, youâ€™ll get a merge conflict. If this happens, youâ€™ll need to resolve the issues following the steps in the last chapter (see: How to resolve a merge conflict.

In your R Studio file pane, you should now see the 01-plot.qmd file listed (you may need to refresh).

Next up
Now that you understand the basics of how to make feature branches and have an baseline understanding of how merging works, weâ€™ll show you how to use Githubâ€™s pull request feature to review changes and get feedback (the workflow weâ€™d recommend).

title: 19Â  Pull requests
text:
19.1 Suggest and Review Changes with Pull Requests
Pull Requests (often abbreviated to just â€œPRâ€ in the programming world) are GitHubâ€™s way of saying, â€œHey, Iâ€™ve made some changes. Can we look them over and maybe merge them into the main project?â€
Even if youâ€™re working solo, theyâ€™re a great habit because they give you a space to:
Weâ€™ll walk through the basic pull request workflow below.

title: 19Â  Pull requests
text:
Review your changes before merging.
Track a discussion about the changes youâ€™re making with your collaborators.
Ensure everything looks good before merging.

title: 20Â  Quick reference
text: 20.1 Common commands

title: 20Â  Quick reference
text:
ğŸ’» Command
ğŸ’¬ Description
ğŸ› ï¸ Task




git status
See which files are staged, unstaged, or untracked
Check file status


git diff
See whatâ€™s changed but not yet staged
View unstaged changes


git add filename
Add a specific file to the staging area
Stage a specific file


git add .
Add everything in the directory
Stage all changes


git commit -m "Message here"
Save your staged changes with a message
Commit staged changes


git push
Upload your commits to the remote repository
Push commits to GitHub

title: 19Â  Quick reference
text: 19.2 Terminology

title: 19Â  Troubleshooting
text:
Common scenarios and fixes
Even experienced developers forget a command or hit a weird error sometimes. You will mess up Git at some point. Thatâ€™s part of the learning process!
Hereâ€™s how to recover from common problems and feel less stuck.

title: 19Â  Troubleshooting
text:
â€œI made a change I donâ€™t want anymoreâ€
Scenario 1: you changed a file but havenâ€™t committed it yet.
Run:
git restore filename.qmd
This resets the file to how it was in your last commit.
Scenario 2: you changed a file and already staged it (git add <filename>)
First, unstage it by running:
git restore --staged filename.qmd
Then run:
git restore filename.qmd


â€œI committed the wrong thingâ€
You can undo the most recent commit (without losing your changes):
git reset --soft HEAD~1
Now your changes are back in the staging area. Fix what you need, and recommit.
If you want to undo the commit and all your changes:
git reset --hard HEAD~1
âš ï¸ Warning: Using --hard will delete your work â€” only use this if youâ€™re really sure!


â€œI forgot to add a file before committingâ€
If you made a commit but forgot a file you meant to include:
Step 1: Stage the missing file:
git add missed_file.qmd
Step 2: Amend your last commit:
git commit --amend
This opens the Terminalâ€™s default text editor, Vim, so you can update the message or leave it the same. Git will include the new file in the same commit.
After editing your message in Vim:

Press Esc to make sure youâ€™re not in insert mode.
Type :wq (stands for write and quit).
Press Enter / returnto save you changes and exit Vim.



â€œI canâ€™t push because â€˜tip of your current branch is behindâ€™â€
This means someone else pushed changes to GitHub before you.
To fix it:
git pull --rebase
This fetches the new work and replays your changes on top of it. If thereâ€™s a conflict, Git will pause and ask you to resolve it. Once done, run:
git add . git rebase --continue
Then push again:
git push

title: Intro to Terminal & Git for R
text:
About this book
Intro to Terminal and Git for R is a series of lessons and instructions used for courses in the School of Journalism and Media, Moody College of Communication at the University of Texas at Austin. This book is the brainchild of Associate Professor of Practice Christian McDonald, but has primarily been written by Anastasia Goodwin.

title: Intro to Terminal & Git for R
text:
Some words from the authors
There is always more than one way to do things in coding. This book is an opinionated collection of lessons intended to teach students new to programming how to get started using the command line and version control. We consider our audiences beginners, and strive to make steps as simple as possible, which means we may not go into detail about alternative (and possibly better) ways to accomplish tasks in favor of reducing options to simplify understanding. For our purposes, we stick to the basics in hopes it eliminates enough of the noise for our students to get their feet on the ground using these technologies.
There are a multitude of other resources available to students once they advance beyond the materials in this book, and we strongly encourage them to Google and seek out additional information about the concepts covered in this guide for further learning.

title: Intro to Terminal & Git for R
section: Conventions and styles in this book
text:
Conventions and styles in this book
We hold the deep belief that â€œall ships rise with the tideâ€ when members of the data journalism community learn together, and this book seeks to add to that mission. Weâ€™ve written this textbook in the first-person plural to foster a sense of collaboration and shared learning between the reader and the authors. By using pronouns like â€œweâ€ and â€œour,â€ our guide invites students into a learning journey that feels supportive and inclusive, rather than distant or instructional. It reflects the idea that learning to code is not a solitary task, but a process that many people engage in together. Our aim for this guide is to help beginners feel less intimidated, encouraging them to see mistakes and discoveries as part of a shared experience, not personal failures.
We will try to be consistent in the way we write documentation and lessons, but we are human and sometimes we break my own rules. In general, keep the following in mind:

Things to do
Things to DO are in ordered lists:

Do this thing.
Then do this thing.

Explanations are usually in text, like this very paragraph.
Sometimes details will be explained in lists:

This is the first thing I want you to know.
This is the second. You donâ€™t have to DO these things, just know about them.



Code blocks
This book often runs the code that is shown, so youâ€™ll see the code and the result of that code below it.

1 + 1

[1] 2



Copying code blocks
When you see code in the instructions, you can roll your cursor over the right-corner and click on the copy icon to copy the code clock content to your clipboard.

You can then paste the code inside your coding program chunk.
That said, typing code yourself has many, many benefits. You learn better when you type yourself, make mistakes and have to fix them. We encourage you to always type short code snippets. Leave the copying to long ones.


Hidden code
Sometimes we want to include code in the book but not display it so you can try the to write the code yourself first. When we do this, it will look like this:


Click here to show the code
1 + 1


[1] 2


If you click on the triangle or the words that follow, youâ€™ll reveal the code. Click again to hide it.


Annotated code
Sometimes when we are explaining code it is helpful to match lines of code to the explanation about them, which we do through annotated code.

1mtcars |>
2  head()


1

First we take the Motor Trend Car Road Tests data set AND THEN â€¦

2

We pipe into the head() command, which gives us the â€œtopâ€ of the data.




                   mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb
Mazda RX4         21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4
Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4
Datsun 710        22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1
Hornet 4 Drive    21.4   6  258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44  1  0    3    1
Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8  360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02  0  0    3    2
Valiant           18.1   6  225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22  1  0    3    1


When there are annotations like this you have to be careful if you are copying code from the book. Either copy it one line at a time or use the copy icon noted above.


Fenced code
Sometimes we need to show code chunk options that are added, like when explaining how to name chunks. In those cases, you may see the code chunk with all the tick marks, etc. like this:

```{r block-named}
1 + 1
```

[1] 2


or

```{r}
#| label: block-named-yaml

1 + 1
```

[1] 2


You can still copy/paste these blocks, but youâ€™ll get the entire code block, not just the contents.



Notes, some important
We will use information callouts to set off a less important aside:






Markdown was developed by JOHN GRUBER, as outlined on his Daring Fireball blog.



But sometimes those asides are important. We usually indicate that by using:






Important



You really should learn how to use Markdown as you will use it the whole semester, and hopefully for the rest of your life.


Or we may use a caution callout:






Caution



Not learning Markdown may result in you earning less than stellar grades.

text:
About the authors

Anastasia Goodwin
I am a former web developer and UX/UI designer turned data journalist.
