title: 2Â  Introduction to the terminal
text:
2.1 What is the terminal?
In this chapter, weâ€™ll introduce what the terminal is, and discuss how we interact with it by speaking its language. Weâ€™ll also open your first terminal window, run your first command, and see the terminal â€œtalk backâ€ to us.
Think of using the terminal like dmâ€™ing your computer.
Instead of clicking buttons or opening folders with a mouse or trackpad, you type commands in the command line asking your computer to do these things for you. Your computer reads your message and replies by immediately doing what you ask.
The Terminal (on Mac) or Git Bash (on Windows) are the names of the programs that can run a shell. They are just the text-based user interfaces where you will type these commands.
The terminal might look a little old-school (and letâ€™s be real: a bit scary ğŸ‘»), but itâ€™s one of the most powerful tools you can learn. People who work in code, data, security, and tech use it all the time.
Hereâ€™s just a few examples of what we can ask our computers to do using the terminal:
We can do all of these things by typing just a few words. But to communicate effectively with our terminals, we have to learn â€œspeakâ€ its language. In this guide, youâ€™ll learn the basics of this language to get you started.

title: 2Â  Introduction to the terminal
text:
Terminology note



People (including the authors of this guide) will use the term shell, terminal and command line interchangeably. This means when we say â€œtype into your shellâ€, â€œin your command lineâ€, or â€œin your terminalâ€, we mean type at the prompt in your Terminal or Git Bash program. Later, weâ€™ll use our Terminal from within Visual Studio Code.
In reality, there are some nuances:

The terminal opens a window.
Inside that, a shell runs.
You interact with it through the command line interface.

In practical terms, just know they usually mean the same thing out in the wild.





List all the files in a folder
Create a new folder
Install programs
Move files around
Automate tasks

title: 2Â  Introduction to the terminal
text:
2.2 Speaking the terminalâ€™s language
The programming language we will use for our interactions in the terminal is called Bash. Bash is a Unix-based program and most of the Internet runs on Unix (or Linux) computers.
Macs understand Bash natively, but Windows doesnâ€™t understand Bash at all without the help of another program. This is why we downloaded Git and Git Bash in the prerequisites â€“ so we can all speak the same language, regardless of the machines weâ€™re using.

title: 2Â  Introduction to the terminal
text:
2.3 How to Open the Terminal
First things first, we need to actually open the Terminal on our machines.

macOSWindows



For Macs, press Command + Space to launch Spotlight, then type Terminal, and hit Enter / return.
Once you launch it will look like this (though it may have a white screen):



Mac Terminal


Look at the very top line to see if the term in the middle of the title bar is bash like above. If it says zsh instead, go to the Change Mac shell to bash section in the troubleshooting chapter to fix it.

Tip: If you want, you can change the Terminalâ€™s theme to make it more comfortable to look at by following the steps in the how to change your Terminal theme appendix.



For Windows you can go to your Start menu and type in Git Bash and launch it.

It will look like this:



Windows Git Bash


Tip: If you want, you can change the Terminalâ€™s theme to make it more comfortable to look at by following the steps in the how to change your Terminal theme appendix

title: 2Â  Introduction to the terminal
section: 2.4 Your First Command: Saying Hello to the Terminal
text:
2.4 Your First Command: Saying Hello to the Terminal
Ok, now that the terminal window is open on your computer, letâ€™s take a quick look at the text showing in the window when you launch to familiarize ourselves with basics of the interface.






Note for newer Mac users



When you launch the Terminal for the first time, youâ€™ll probably see a prompt saying something like:
The default interactive shell is now zsh.
To update your account to use zsh, please run `chsh -s /bin/zsh`.
DISREGARD THIS MESSAGE. Do not run this the command to update to zsh. Zsh is a similar language that Mac is transitioning to by default. However, we will use Bash for this guide to keep everyone on the same page, regardless of their operating systems.
If you accidentally switched to zsh already, go to the Change Mac shell to bash section in the troubleshooting chapter to fix it.





When you launch Terminal for the first time, youâ€™ll see some text like this.


Letâ€™s breakdown a few things from the screenshot above:

Computer name: the characters before the ~ is your computerâ€™s name (you may not have known it even had one).
Current directory: The ~ character is Terminal shorthand for your â€œbaseâ€ directory on your computer. The value shown here will update as you move around to different folders on your computer.
User name: The part immediately after the ~ is your username.
Command prompt: Lastly we have the $. This is the â€œpromptâ€ where you type commands. (Note: if youâ€™re on a Mac and see a % instead of a â€œ$â€, you may not be in Bash. Fix that by going to the Change Mac shell to bash section in the troubleshooting chapter)

You type your commands AFTER the $ and then hit Enter / return on your keyboard to run or execute them. Weâ€™ll practice doing just that in the next section.

2.4.1 Your First Command: Saying Hello to the Terminal
Letâ€™s try your first real command: finding out where you are using the command pwd.

In the terminal prompt (remember, after the $), type the following command:

Press Enter / return to run the command.

You should see Terminal respond with something like this:
/Users/yourname
or this
C:\Users\yourname
Depending on your system, the path may look a little different â€” and thatâ€™s OK.
So what just happened?

pwd stands for â€œprint working directory.â€
It simply asks: Where am I right now in the computerâ€™s folder system?
Your computer provides the following answer: your current folder â€” usually your â€œhomeâ€ directory when you first open the Terminal.

title: 3Â  Moving around in the terminal

3.1 Whatâ€™s in this folder? (ls)
Now that you know where you are (pwd), itâ€™s time to explore whatâ€™s around you. Specifically, weâ€™ll start by moving between different folders on your computer.

When your first launch terminal, youâ€™ll see a ~ (called a tilde), which lets you know youâ€™re in your base or home directory. We want to ask the terminal to tell us what is inside this home directory.
To ask terminal whatâ€™s inside a directory:
Terminal will respond to your command with a list of files and folders like this:
Your list may be different depending on whatâ€™s in your computerâ€™s home folder. Thatâ€™s ok!
In any case, the list of directories returned by Terminal will match the folders you would see if you clicked on your home directory in the Finder on a Mac or in File Explorer on a Windows machine. For example, the list of folders listed in the example response above matches what we see in our home directory using Finder below.
Quick Recap on the ls command:

3.2 Moving around (cd)

cd stands for change directory.

In terminal, we use the cd command â€“ shorthand for â€œchange directoryâ€ â€“ to move into and out of folders.
Suppose you ran your ls command and see a folder called Documents. If you wanted to move into that folder, youâ€™d do the following:

3.3 How Can You Tell Where You Are Now? (pwd)

3.6 ğŸ”¥ Pro Tip: speed up with tab completion
Ok, now that youâ€™ve got some practice typing things into terminal, weâ€™ll let you in on a big time-saver: when you start typing a folder name, you donâ€™t have to type the whole thing.

title: 4Â  Making and managing folder
text:
4.1 Creating a Folder (mkdir)
Now that you can move around the Terminal like a pro, itâ€™s time to create your own stuff.
In this chapter, weâ€™ll learn to make new folders and files. Weâ€™ll also learn how to move or delete them.
Letâ€™s say you wanted to make a brand new folder on your computer. If you were doing this in Finder, youâ€™d do something like right click inside your folder, and click on New Folder in the menu. Then youâ€™d need to fill out your folder name and save the folder.
To do this from the command line, however, we do all of these steps in a single prompt using the mkdir command.
For example, if you ran the following command from inside your home directory (~) (donâ€™t do this):
This would create a new folder called my_new_folder inside your directory. Weâ€™ll practice doing this in the next step.

3.3 Creating a File (touch)
Like folders, we can also make new files from the command line using the touch command.

title: 4Â  Making and managing folder
text:
4.5 Copying files and folders (cp)

cp is shorthand for â€œcopyâ€

We can also make duplicate files or folders from command line using the cp command.
Unlike the other commands weâ€™ve learned so far, the cp commands takes two arguments instead of just one. â€œArgumentsâ€ are just the pieces of information you feed the command line to tell it what to do. For example, in the cd Documents command, â€œDocumentsâ€ was the argument telling the command line to go inside the Documents folder.
Syntax of the cp command

cp source_file_folder destination_file_folder

The cp command takes at least two arguments:

Source file or folder: the file or folder you want to copy.
Destination file or folder: the name youâ€™d like the copy of the file or folder to be called.

title: 4Â  Making and managing folder
text:
4.7 Moving or Renaming Files (mv)

mv is shorthand for â€œmoveâ€

Moving files or folders from command line is also easy using the mv command. The command can also by used to rename files, depending on the syntax you use.
Syntax of the mv command
To move a fileâ€™s location, use the following syntax:

If you just want to rename a file, use the following syntax:

Weâ€™ll practice the two different ways to use the mv command in the next exercise.

title: 4Â  Making and managing folder
text:
4.9 Deleting files and folders (rm)

rm is shorthand for â€œremoveâ€

You can also use the command line to delete files and folders on your machine using the rm command.
This command does require some caution because when you delete something from the terminal, it doesnâ€™t go to the Trash â€” itâ€™s just gone.






Important



Be very careful when using the rm command. Any files you delete this way do not go to Trash, and will be unrecoverable. Make sure that you really want to delete your files or folder before proceeding. Additionally, deleting a folder deletes everything inside of that folder as well.


Syntax of the rm command:
Deleting a single file:
rm name_file_to_delete
Deleting a folder (and everything inside it):
rm -r folder_to_delete
What does that -r mean?

The -r here is called a flag. The one here stands for â€œrecursiveâ€ â€” it tells rm command to delete not just the folder, but also everything thatâ€™s inside it. Weâ€™ll talk a little more about flags in the next section.

title: 4Â  Making and managing folder
text:
4.10 Quick Note About Flags ğŸ³ï¸
Flags are just another type of argument you can add to commands to change how they behave.

Theyâ€™re usually a dash plus one or two letters. (Example: -r means â€œrecursiveâ€ for the rm command)
Each command has its own set of flags that it understands. A flag that works with one command wonâ€™t necessarily work with another.
You can combine flags (like rm -rf which combines the -r flag for â€œrecursiveâ€ and -f flag for â€œforce deleteâ€).

Youâ€™ll see flags often out in the wild. As you use the command line more, youâ€™ll start to use more of these flags in your workflow to give you more control over what your commands do. For now, just know when you see something starting with a dash in the command line, itâ€™s probably a flag giving the command a little extra information about what to do.
Optional mini exercise:
If you want, you can try one out yourself now by using the -l flag along with the ls command.The flag tells the command line, â€œgive me more information about each file in my directoryâ€.
Run the following command to see this flag in action:

Terminal will respond with detailed information about each file and folder in your directory. See the screenshot below for more information about each detail field.



Breakdown of each file detail in the -l flag Terminal response

title: 5Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
5.1 Command History
In this brief chapter, weâ€™ll touch on a few things that should help you work quicker in the Terminal. Weâ€™ll also touch on navigating common issues youâ€™ll probably run into.
The command line keeps a history of the commands you give it. Much like scrolling back up through the messages in a conversation on your phone, you can â€œscroll upâ€ through the conversation youâ€™ve had with the terminal (only with the terminal, youâ€™ll only see the messages you sent).
How to view your command history:
To see prior commands youâ€™ve written, just press the up arrow â†‘ on your keyboard. Each press will take you to the prior command in your history.
To get back to an empty prompt, scroll back down using the down arrow â†“
You can re-run any command that pops up simply by hitting the Enter / return key on your keyboard. No need to re-type things!
Why this is useful
In programming, we repeat commands quite frequently (think about how often you re-run your notebook code in R-Studio, for example).
Having a command history is helpful because it:
crumbs: 5Â  Command line tips and tricks

title: 5Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
Saves time â€“ You can quickly repeat or modify previous commands with the â†‘ key instead of retyping them.
Reduces mistakes â€“ Reusing known, valid commands lowers the chance of typos or syntax errors.
Aids in learning â€“ You can review what youâ€™ve done, which helps you remember your steps and can help with troubleshooting if something goes wrong.
crumbs: 5Â  Command line tips and tricks

title: 5Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
5.2 Canceling a Command
One of the scariest things for new command line users happens when you run something you didnâ€™t mean to. Weâ€™ve been walking through things slowly and together in this guide, but youâ€™ll be more on your own in the real world, and we promise you will mess up at some point.
If you realize you made a mistake while a command is running, press:
Ctrl + C
This cancels the running command and brings you back to the prompt.

title: 5Â  Command line tips and tricks
text:
5.3 Tab Completion
You read about this in chapter 2, but itâ€™s worth mentioning again because itâ€™s that good.
Remember: start typing a folder or file name, press Tab, and Terminal finishes it for you if possible.
It saves time and typos!
If thereâ€™s more than one similarly-named files in your folder, you may have to type more characters to get to the one you want. You can also hit Tab again to see a list of possible matches to help guide you.

title: 6Â  Troubleshooting
text:
6.1 Common pitfalls and errors
In this final chapter, letâ€™s touch quickly on navigating common issues you might run into using the terminal.
Hereâ€™s a quick rundown of the most common problems and errors youâ€™ll run into using the command line. Even experienced developers run into these issues, so learning what they mean will go a long way when troubleshooting.
For more common issues and how to fix them, see the Common errors table in the Glossary at the end of this guide.

title: 6Â  Troubleshooting
text:
Command not found? You might have a typo or the program isnâ€™t installed.
No such file or directory? You might be trying to access a file/path that doesnâ€™t exist. Check that the file exists and that you spelled it correctly. You could also not be in the directory you think you are â€” try running pwd or ls to check your location, then use the cd to navigate where you should be if needed.
Permission denied?
You tried to do something you donâ€™t have permission to do. Check your file/repo permissions.
Syntax error
You typed a command in a way the shell doesnâ€™t understand. Check that your syntax is correct and error-free.
Stuck in a weird app inside Terminal?
Try pressing Ctrl + C or Ctrl + D to exit. (You may need to checkout â€œHow to get out of Vimâ€ below)

title: 6Â  Troubleshooting
section: 6.2 How to Get Out of Vim
text:
6.2 How to Get Out of Vim
Every new command line user shares one panic-inducing experience at one point or another: accidentally opening Vim and not knowing how to get out of it.
In this section, weâ€™ll briefly walk you through what Vim is and how to exit it so you donâ€™t panic when this (inevitably) happens to you.
What is Vim?
Vim is a text editor built into most Unix systems, including macOS and Linux. Itâ€™s used by developers to edit code and configuration files, but it works very differently from regular text editors.
If you accidentally open something in Vim (for example, by running git commit without a message), it might look like youâ€™re stuck. But donâ€™t worry â€” hereâ€™s how to exit safely.
How to Exit Vim
If you donâ€™t want to save any changes (most common):

Press Esc - to make sure youâ€™re not in input mode.
Type :q! - to â€œquit and ignore changesâ€.
Hit Enter / return - to exit.

If You do want to save changes (less common):

Press Esc
Type :wq (to â€œwrite and quitâ€).
Press Enter / return

text:

Youâ€™ve built a real foundation for anything else youâ€™ll learn later â€” whether thatâ€™s coding, scripting, data science, or just being more powerful with your own computer.
Remember: the terminal is your friend.
Keep practicing â€” the more you use it, the more natural it will feel.
Good job! ğŸš€

âŒ Error

command not found
You typed a command the shell doesnâ€™t recognize

Is a directory

You should now you have two files: the original (notes.txt) and the new copy (copy_of_notes.txt).
As we said before, the cp command can also copy whole directories. However, itâ€™s a little more nuanced. If youâ€™d like to learn more about copying folders, please see appendix [TK]
ğŸ“ A note about destination folders: Bash will check to see if the folder you gave it already exists. If it doesnâ€™t, Bash will create the new folder for you and place the file inside of it.

title: 4Â  Making and managing folder
section: 4.6 ğŸ“ Mini excercise: copy a file
text:
4.6 ğŸ“ Mini excercise: copy a file
Now, try letâ€™s try out the cp command on our own by making a copy of notes file you made inside your terminal_practice in the last exercise.
Do the following to copy your notes file:

Run the following from inside your terminal_practice folder:
cp notes.txt copy_of_notes.txt
Run the ls command to see the files inside your folder.

You should now you have two files: the original (notes.txt) and the new copy (copy_of_notes.txt).
As we said before, the cp command can also copy whole directories. However, itâ€™s a little more nuanced. If youâ€™d like to learn more about copying folders, please see appendix [TK]

title: 4Â  Making and managing folder
section: 4.8 ğŸ“ Mini exercise: move and rename a file
text:
4.8 ğŸ“ Mini exercise: move and rename a file
In this exercise weâ€™ll practice both renaming and moving files using the copy of your notes file you made in the previous exercise.
Exercise part 1: move your notes copy file

First, make a new directory by running the following command from inside your terminal_practice directory:
mkdir my_new_folder
Now, peek at your files and folders by running the ls inside your terminal_practice folder. Make sure the new folder is there.
Next, weâ€™ll move the copy of your notes files into your new sub-folder by running:
mv copy_of_notes.txt my_new_folder/
Now, run the ls command again to look at the files inside your terminal_practice folder. You should still see a new folder called my_new_folder, but you should not see the copy of your notes file.

Next, weâ€™ll locate the copy of our notes file:

Run the following command to move into your new folder:
cd my_new_folder
Now run ls to peek at the files. You should see your copy of the notes file listed.

Exercise part 2: rename a file
Ok now that weâ€™ve moved and located our copy of our notes file, letâ€™s rename it something nicer.

From inside your new folder, run the following command to rename your notes copy:
mv copy_of_notes.txt notes_new.txt
Run the ls to look at your files. You should see the copy of your notes files, but now with a new, cleaner name.

Great job! Youâ€™re now well on your way to managing files and folders directly from the command line.

title: 2Â  Introduction to the terminal
text:
Terminology note



People (including the authors of this guide) will use the term shell, terminal and command line interchangeably. This means when we say â€œtype into your shellâ€, â€œin your command lineâ€, or â€œin your terminalâ€, we mean type at the prompt in your Terminal or Git Bash program. Later, weâ€™ll use our Terminal from within Visual Studio Code.
In reality, there are some nuances:

The terminal opens a window.
Inside that, a shell runs.
You interact with it through the command line interface.

In practical terms, just know they usually mean the same thing out in the wild.





List all the files in a folder
Create a new folder
Install programs
Move files around
Automate tasks

title: 1Â  Welcome & Install
text:
Prerequisites
Welcome to the Intro to Terminal guide! We hope this guide will be a resource for you to learn the basics of working with the command line.
If youâ€™ve never opened a Terminal window before, youâ€™re not alone. This guide is here to show you that the command line isnâ€™t something to fear. Itâ€™s just a different way to tell your computer what to do â€” directly, and often much faster.
You donâ€™t need to memorize anything right now. You donâ€™t need to be a â€œtech wizard.â€ You just need a little curiosity.
This guide covers how to use command-line interface tools that allow us to work with our computer through text commands, which is essential in programming.
On Macintosh computers, the program to use weâ€™ll use is called Terminal and it is already installed.
Windows computers are set up a bit differently, so to work in the same environment as Mac users, weâ€™ll need to install Git â€” which also includes Git Bash â€” before moving forward.

title: 1Â  Welcome & Install
text:
How to use this book
Before you dive in, we want to highlight a few things about how weâ€™ve structured the guide to ensure you get the most of your learning experience.
As you work through the guide, we strongly recommend that you do the following:

Type your commands: Getting used to writing in the command line is key to learning and remembering common commands. Though many of the code blocks in this books allow you to copy the code inside, please try to type it yourself (at least on the first try). You can always copy if you run into errors.
Do the mini exercises: There will be small exercises throughout this guide to reinforce learning and get you more comfortable working in the Terminal. Learning to code is largely done through doing, so we highly recommend you take the time to do all of them.
Do the chapters in order: The mini exercises and content in this book are structured to build upon each other. Your first time through, we recommend you complete each chapter along with the mini-exercises in chronological order to ensure you donâ€™t miss steps you need later on.
Read the terminology notes: Throughout this guide, there will be several callout boxes titled â€œterminology notesâ€. These callouts will be used to explain key terms â€“ especially those used interchangeably â€“ that may be confusing to new programmers. We recommend you take the time to read them because knowing the language coders use will help when reading documentation and when seeking help in online spaces like Stack Overflow.

Time to enter the Matrix, Neo.



Fun fact: the original design for the green â€œdigital rainâ€ animation used in the Matrix was based on scans of the creatorâ€™s wifeâ€™s Japanese cookbook.



Next up:
Weâ€™ll learn how to move around inside your computer using simple commands. Whenever youâ€™re ready, proceed to the next chapter.

title: 9Â  Welcome
text:
Who is this guide for?
Welcome to the Intro to Git guide! We hope this guide will be a resource for you to learn the basics of working with version control for the first time.
This guide is for students who know some R and want to learn Git and GitHub to manage and collaborate on R projects (especially Quarto ones). It assumes little-to-no hands-on terminal experience but will encourage building confidence over time by interacting with Github through the command line.
Students who are brand new to the terminal may also find it helpful to go through the Intro to Terminal section of this book before working through this guide.

title: 9Â  Welcome
text:
Prerequisites
Before we move on to working with Git and Github, we need to make sure you have what you need to successfully complete the exercises in this guide. The guide assumes you already have the following installed on your computer:

R
RStudio
Quarto

If you are missing any these, please go to the links listed and make sure to install before moving on to the next chapter!
If you need additional help with installing, you may find it helpful to reference the steps to set up your machine in the â€œInstall Partyâ€ chapter of the Reporting with Data in R book by Professor Christian McDonald.

title: 9Â  Welcome
text:
How to use this book
Before you dive in, we want to highlight a few things about how weâ€™ve structured the guide to ensure you get the most of your learning experience.
As you work through the guide, we strongly recommend that you do the following:

Type your commands: Getting used to writing git commands in the command line is key to learning and remembering workflows. Though many of the code blocks in this books allow you to copy the code inside, please try to type it yourself (at least on the first try). You can always copy if you run into errors.
Do the mini exercises: There will be small exercises throughout this guide to reinforce learning and get you more comfortable working in the Terminal and Git. Learning to code is largely done through doing, so we highly recommend you take the time to do all of them.
Do the chapters in order: The mini exercises and content in this book are structured to build upon each other. Your first time through, we recommend you complete each chapter along with the mini-exercises in chronological order to ensure you donâ€™t miss steps you need later on.
Read the terminology notes: Throughout this guide, there will be several callout boxes titled â€œterminology notesâ€. These callouts will be used to explain key terms â€“ especially those used interchangeably â€“ that may be confusing to new programmers. We recommend you take the time to read them because knowing the language coders use will help when reading documentation and when seeking help in online spaces like Stack Overflow.

title: 10Â  Introduction to version control
text:
10.2 What is Git?
To keep track of versions of coding projects, programmers use a version control tool called Git. It runs on your computer and helps you:

Track changes you make to your project files.
Save â€œsnapshotsâ€ (called commits) of your project over time.
Go back to an earlier snapshot if needed.
See what exactly changed between versions.
Work with teammates without messing up each othersâ€™ work.

You can think of Git like the â€œsave gameâ€ feature on a video game. Instead of saving the progress of your character in your game, Git saves your progress in your coding files. But just like in many games, we have to tell Git when and how to save a new version.
This is where Github comes in.

title: 10Â  Introduction to version control
text:
10.3 What is Github?
GitHub is a website that hosts Git repositories (your project + its history) online.
Github lets you:

Store your Git project safely in the cloud.
Share your project with others.
Collaborate with other people (even if they are far away).
Keep a backup in case your computer crashes.

If Git is a notebook where you track all your work, GitHub is like an online library where you can store a copy of that notebook â€” and invite others to read it or even help you write in it.

title: 10Â  Introduction to version control
text:
10.4 Checkpoint
In this chapter you learned some about version control and the tools we use to access it.
Letâ€™s quickly recap those tools before moving on:

Version control: the system of tracking changes to your files over time so you can revisit or undo edits, collaborate with others, and keep a history of your work.
Git: a version control tool you use on your computer to track changes.
GitHub: a website where you can upload (and share) your Git projects.


Next up:
Weâ€™ll install Git and get our computers setup to start tracking changes. When youâ€™re ready, move onto the the next chapter.

title: 11Â  Installation and setup
text:
11.3 Setup your SSH Keys (Authenticating)
Authentication is just a fancy term to describe proving that you are who you say you are. In other words, itâ€™s how you â€œsign inâ€ to your Github using the command line. We need to do this so you can connect your project to your Github account and make changes.
Without authentication, GitHub wonâ€™t let you push changes, clone private repositories, or do other actions that affect your account. Itâ€™s how GitHub keeps your code safe and makes sure only you can access your stuff.
There are a couple of ways to authenticate with Github from your computer. The book Happy Git with R recommends using personal access tokens (basically a long password) and that is fine. We prefer the one-and-done nature of SSH keys, so that is the method we will use in this guide.
Instead of using passwords, SSH keys are basically a lock and key system that have to match in order for your computer to access your Github accounts.
You can think of SSH keys like this:

ğŸ”’ Public key = A â€œlockâ€ you give to GitHub
ğŸ”‘ Private key = Your secret â€œkeyâ€ that opens that lock

Together, they let Github know that itâ€™s really you (or rather your local machine) who is connecting.
Weâ€™ll walk through getting SSH keys setup on your machine in the next steps!






Terminology note



When people (including the authors of this guide) use the terms â€œlocal machine,â€ â€œlocal computer,â€ or just â€œyour machine,â€ theyâ€™re all talking about your personal computer â€” the one youâ€™re using right now.
Itâ€™s called â€œlocalâ€ to distinguish it from a remote machine (like a server or computer somewhere else, often in the cloud) that you connect to over the internet.



11.3.1 Enable version control in RStudio
First, weâ€™ll enable version control in RStudio by doing the following:

Launch RStudio.
Go to the menu Tools > Global Options, then click on the Git/SVN tab.
Check the Enable version control interface for RStudio button.
There should already be a path included in the git executable field.
Make sure the path to the git executable is correct.

If it is not, try quitting RStudio and relaunching it and do this step again.
If it is still not there, talk to your professor. Weâ€™ll find it.





Git/SVN window




11.3.2 Create a new SSH key
Next, weâ€™ll check if your SSH key is already setup:

In the Git/SVN window, look for the SSH key field.
If you SSH Key path is already filled in, then you can skip to the â€œAdd SSH Keys on Githubâ€ section. If you do not have an SSH key showing, follow the next steps below to make one before moving on.

If youâ€™ve never used SSH keys before, youâ€™ll have to create one, but RStudio makes that fairly painless.

Click on the Create RSA Key button.
You should be able to leave all the defaults as they are. Leave the optional Passphrase field blank.
Click the Create button.
You should see a message that says â€œKey Created Successfullyâ€ and it might show you a pretty picture. Click OK.




SSH Key Creation window

title: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
section: 13.4 Staging: Adding the files you do want (git add)
text:
13.4 Staging: Adding the files you do want (git add)
Now that weâ€™ve told Git what we donâ€™t want to keep track of, we need to tell Git what we do want to track â€“ in our case, the rest of our files. Weâ€™ll do that by using the git add command.
Letâ€™s add our project files.

Type the run the following command in your terminal:
git add .

The . after the add means â€œadd everything in this folderâ€ (ignoring anything listed in .gitignore.)

Now, check your project files by running git status again.

The output should look something like this now:
On branch main

No commits yet

Changes to be committed:
  (use "git rm --cached <file>..." to unstage)
        new file:   .gitignore
        new file:   _quarto.yml
        new file:   my-git-quarto-project.Rproj
        new file:   my-git-quarto-project.qmd
Notice that the heading has changed to â€œChanges to be committedâ€ and files are now shown in green. The process you just went through is called Staging your files.
crumbs: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files

title: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
section: 13.5 Committing: take your first Snapshot (git commit)
text:
13.5 Committing: take your first Snapshot (git commit)
Now that youâ€™ve told Git which files you care about, itâ€™s time to take a â€œsnapshotâ€ of these files.

Run the following in your command line:
git commit -m "Initial commit: set up Quarto project"

Ok, so what did we just do?

Took a snapshot: We told Git â€œsave a copy of the version of the files we just addedâ€ using the git commit command
Added a description of the snapshot: the -m is a flag that stands for â€œmessageâ€. The message describes the changes you made in your files, and every commit needs a commit message. The commit message is included inside a set of quotation marks.

Weâ€™ll talk more about commit messages in the next chapter, but for now know that they are a required and important part of the git workflow.
crumbs: 13Â  Add, ignore, and commit files

title: 13Â  Pushing to Github
section: 13.3 Quick Recap: what do these cmmands do?
text:
13.3 Quick Recap: what do these cmmands do?
Ok, we just did a lot there. Letâ€™s pause for a moment and breakdown everything we just did:

git remote add origin {REPO_URL}: Told Git where your online repository lives (on GitHub).
git push -u origin main
This command did two things:

Setup a link between your local main branch and the main branch on GitHub.
â€œPushedâ€ your local commits (aka the â€œsnapshotâ€ we took last section) to GitHub.


In short, these steps connected your local project to your remote project on Github, then saved the snapshot you took to the cloud. We wonâ€™t have to repeat these exact steps ever again when saving snapshots in the future for this project.
That said, is the process you will follow when making new Github projects in the future, so make sure you understand the basics of what we did here.
ğŸ‰ Congratulations: you now have your first live project is on GitHub!

title: 14Â  Updating files
text:
14.3 Stage the Change (git add...)
Now that you know Git sees the change, you need to tell Git, â€œHey, save this file in the next snapshot.â€
Like with our initial commit, youâ€™ll prep your files by adding â€” or staging â€” them for your next commit.
This time around, weâ€™re going to be a bit more surgical with the files we commit by only adding the individual file rather than using the . to add all files.
To stage only your index file:

Run the following:
git add 01-index.qmd
Check your Git status again by running:
git status

You should see your 01-index.qmd file in green, along with following message:
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git restore --staged <file>..." to unstage)
  modified:   01-index.qmd`
ğŸ‰ Great! Your changed file is now staged and ready to commit.

title: 15Â  Updating files
text:
15.4 Commit your change (git commit -m)
Now, weâ€™ll save the snapshot of our updated file in Gitâ€™s memory. Remember, when we save snapshots, we need to include a descriptive commit message noting what we changed. Git commits always need a message attached to them.
A few best practices to keep in mind when writing commit messages:

Use present tense: "Add summary of...", not "Added...".
Keep things short but descriptive.
Think: â€œWhat changed in this version?â€, then write that in the message.

âœ… Good commit messages make it easier for you and others to pick up where you left off. If something breaks during an update or if you need to go back to a prior version, commit messages will help your retrace your steps.
With those things in mind, letâ€™s practice writing a descriptive commit message for your change to the 01-index.qmd.

Type something like the following and hit enter:
git commit -m "Add summary of mtcars dataset"

Terminal will respond with a summary of insertions and deletions in your file.
A quick word of caution about the -m flag and Vim
Git commits always need a message attached to them. The -m flag tells the command line that weâ€™ll be writing our message inline along with our commit command.
If you forget to include that message flag, the Terminal will open its default text editor called Vim. If you find yourself in this scenario (and you likely will at some point), donâ€™t panic. Thereâ€™s a section on getting out of Vim in our Intro to Terminal book.

title: 15Â  Updating files
section: 15.5 Push your commit to GitHub (git push)
text:
15.5 Push your commit to GitHub (git push)
Now, that our changes are staged and commited, weâ€™ll send the snapshot from your computer to GitHub by pushing our changes.

Push your new commit by running:
git push

Now go to your repository on Github â€” youâ€™ll see your commit listed under the Commits tab and your file under the <>Codetab! (You may need to refresh)
You may be wondering why this push command was shorter than it was last time. In your last push, you needed to connect local project (the one on your computer) to the remote repository on Github and connect your main branches.
Since you already connected your Quarto project to Github and connected your branches, you can just use the git push command now. No need to redo things!

title: 16Â  Project setup and basic workflow
text:
16.1 Basic Git workflow with a team
Now that you can push your changes to GitHub, itâ€™s time to talk about how to collaborate with others on the same project.
One of the best things about keeping your code in a Github repository is that it allows you to collaborate with other people on the same coding project. Now, to make these collaborations work smoothly there are some best practices and processes you will need to follow.
When working in a Git project with other people, the collaboration process builds upon the basic workflow we laid out in the Updating Your Repo chapter.
Before working on your own changes in your local repo, you will pull down the most recent version of the Github project to make sure youâ€™re incorporating the most recent changes to the project. This helps you stay in sync with your team and prevents you from overwriting each othersâ€™ work and creating major conflicts later.
After grabbing the most recent version, each member of your team will then follow the basic git workflow of making changes to the files on their local repository, committing the changes, and pushing the changes up to the shared remote project stored in Github.
Weâ€™ll go over the basics of setting up this kind of shared project below.
crumbs: 16Â  Project setup and basic workflow

title: 16Â  Project setup and basic workflow
section: 16.2 Setting up the shared Github project
text:
16.2 Setting up the shared Github project

16.2.1 Step 1: Create the repo
Only one group member needs to create the GitHub repo (you already know how, just like we did in the Push the Initial Commit to GitHub chapter.
Once the repo is created, the owner can add team members.
To add team members, the owner will do the following:

Go to the repository on GitHub.
Click Settings â†’ Collaborators.
Add the teammateâ€™s GitHub username.

Note: This action will send them an invitation. They must accept it before they can push changes.


16.2.2 Step 2: The collaborator clones the repo
Once added as a collaborator, the second person can make a copy of the repo on their own local machine. This process of copying a repository onto your computer is called cloning in the Git world.
Weâ€™ll walk through how to clone a repo in a moment, but first, letâ€™s make sure you know where you should clone things.
Choose where to clone your repo:

Using the cd command, navigate in your terminal to the folder where you keep your coding projects. For example, a good place for this might be in a projects folder inside your home directory or your Documents folder.
If you need to create a folder for your projects, you can do this in the terminal like this:
cd ~              # Go to your home folder 
mkdir projects    # Make a folder called 'projects' (if it doesn't already exist) 
cd projects       # Move into that folder`

Clone the repo:
Now that youâ€™re in the right place, youâ€™re ready to copy the repo onto your local machine following the steps below.
In Github, do the following:

Navigate to the repo you want to clone.
Click the big, blue <> CODE button (at the top right).
Navigate to the SSH tab in the dropdown menu.
You will see a box with something like: git@github.com:username/repository-name. Click the icon next to this box to copy it to your clipboard.

In your Terminal window,

type the following command, replacing repo name with the one you copied from Github:
git clone git@github.com:username/repository-name
Hit Enter / return to run the command.

This creates a local folder with all of the repoâ€™s contents and Git history within the projects folder on your computer.
You can check to make sure this worked by doing the following:

Run the list command below inside your project folder where you cloned the repo:
ls
Locate the name of your cloned repo in the files list.
Use the cd commmand to navigate into your repo folder, replacing folder_name with your repo name:
the cd folder_name
Now, run the ls command again to see your project files.

You should see a copy of all the project files that matches the version of the project you cloned from Github! Youâ€™re now ready to start collaborating!


16.2.3 Step 3: Everyone pulls before they work
When collaborating with others, itâ€™s important to stay in sync with one another. In Git, we do this by pulling down changes onto our local machines. Essentially this works in the opposite way of pushing changes.
When we use git pull, weâ€™re simply asking Git, â€œHey, can you give me the most recent version of the project, including any changes that were made by my teammates since the last time I worked?â€
Before making any changes in our project, always run from inside your project folder:
git pull
This downloads any changes pushed to GitHub since you last worked from your specific machine. These changes might include changes your teammates made, but could also include changes you made if youâ€™re working on a different computer (yes, you can do that with Git).






Warning



Skipping git pull is more likely to lead to merge conflicts when Git sees two people made changes to the same thing, but they donâ€™t match. We want to avoid this whenever possible to make our project workflow more efficient and less prone to errors.
crumbs: 16Â  Project setup and basic workflow

title: 16Â  Project setup and basic workflow
section: 16.3 Each Person Works, Commits, and Pushes
text:
16.3 Each Person Works, Commits, and Pushes
When working collaboratively on a coding project, your team will follow the basic Git workflow to keep things smooth, clean, and easy to manage.
The basic Git workflow:
You and your teammates take turns:

Making changes locally to project files on your computers.
Staging and committing the changes using Git (git add, git commit -m).
Pushing those changes to GitHub (git push).

And remember, every time you go to work on your project, you and your teammates should pull before making your own edits by using git pull. ğŸ˜‰

Next up:
Youâ€™ll learn what to do if you run into merge conflicts while collaborating.
crumbs: 16Â  Project setup and basic workflow

title: 16Â  Dealing with conflicts
text:
16.2 Why merge conflicts?
When merging, Git is trying to combine the changes from two versions of a file into one. Most of the time, if the changes are in different parts of the files, Git can handle it automatically.
But if two people made edits to the same part of a file (like the same sentence or section), Git doesnâ€™t want to guess whoâ€™s right â€” so it stops and asks you to make the call.
Think of it like this:

Youâ€™re merging two Word documents together.
One version says â€œThe sky is blue.â€
The other version says â€œThe sky is purple.â€
Git says: â€œYou canâ€™t have both. Which one do you want?â€

In Git world, this is a merge conflict, and Git needs your help to resolve it.

16.2.1 How will Git let me know thereâ€™s a conflict?
When Git encounters a merge conflict, two things will happen:

In your Terminal, youâ€™ll see a message like:

Auto-merging filename.qmd CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in analysis.qmd Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.

In the file with the conflict, Git will mark the conflicted lines like this:
<<<<<<< HEAD This is your version. ======= This is your teammateâ€™s version. >>>>>>> abc123

Youâ€™ll need to manually choose which version (or both!) to keep and then commit the right changes to Git. Weâ€™ll walk you through the process of resolving these conflicts in the section below.



16.2.2 Step-by-Step: Resolving a Merge Conflict
Letâ€™s say both you and a collaborator edited the same section of analysis.qmd and now Git is confused when you try to pull or merge.
Step 1: See the Conflict
When you run:
git pull
Git might respond:
Auto-merging analysis.qmd CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in analysis.qmd Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.
Step 2: Open the Conflicted File
Open analysis.qmd in RStudio or your code editor. Youâ€™ll see something like:
<<<<<<< HEAD The sky is blue. ======= The sky is purple. >>>>>>> origin/main
This is Git saying:

<<<<<<< HEAD = your local version
======= = the separator
>>>>>>> origin/main = the version from GitHub (or your teammate)

In other words:

Anything between <<<<<<< HEAD and the ======= separator are your current changes.
Anything between the ======= and >>>>>>> origin/main is whatâ€™s on the Github version.

Step 3: Choose What to Keep
Decide what version is correct. You can:

Keep one
Combine them
Rewrite it entirely

The sky is blue and sometimes purple at sunset.
Note: make sure to delete the conflict markers (<<<<<<<, =======, >>>>>>>) when youâ€™re done.
Step 4: Mark the Conflict as Resolved
Once youâ€™ve fixed the file, you need to tell Git itâ€™s ready:
git add analysis.qmd
Step 5: Commit the Merge
Now complete the merge:
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflict in analysis.qmd"
ğŸ‰ Thatâ€™s it â€” youâ€™ve handled a merge conflict like a pro.

title: 16Â  Dealing with conflicts
text:

When you run:

Git might respond:
Auto-merging analysis.qmd CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in analysis.qmd Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.
Step 2: Open the Conflicted File
Open analysis.qmd in RStudio or your code editor. Youâ€™ll see something like:
<<<<<<< HEAD The sky is blue. ======= The sky is purple. >>>>>>> origin/main
This is Git saying:

<<<<<<< HEAD = your local version
======= = the separator
>>>>>>> origin/main = the version from GitHub (or your teammate)

In other words:

Anything between <<<<<<< HEAD and the ======= separator are your current changes.
Anything between the ======= and >>>>>>> origin/main is whatâ€™s on the Github version.

Step 3: Choose What to Keep
Decide what version is correct. You can:

Keep one
Combine them
Rewrite it entirely

The sky is blue and sometimes purple at sunset.
Note: make sure to delete the conflict markers (<<<<<<<, =======, >>>>>>>) when youâ€™re done.
Step 4: Mark the Conflict as Resolved
Once youâ€™ve fixed the file, you need to tell Git itâ€™s ready:
git add analysis.qmd
Step 5: Commit the Merge
Now complete the merge:
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflict in analysis.qmd"
ğŸ‰ Thatâ€™s it â€” youâ€™ve handled a merge conflict like a pro.

title: 17Â  Dealing with conflicts
section: 17.2 How to resolve a merge conflict
text:
17.2 How to resolve a merge conflict
Letâ€™s say both you and a collaborator edited the same section of analysis.qmd and now Git is confused when you try to pull or merge.
Step 1: read the conflict message
When you run:
git pull
Git might respond with something like this:

Auto-merging analysis.qmd CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in analysis.qmd Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.

This message tells you that the issue is in the file analysis.qmd. This is where youâ€™ll need to resolve a merge conflict.
Step 2: Open the Conflicted File

Open analysis.qmd in RStudio or your code editor.
Find the conflict by looking for the text <<<<<<< HEAD. You can use the find feature (CMD+F) to search in RStudio if needed
Youâ€™ll see something like: <<<<<<< HEAD The sky is blue. ======= The sky is purple. >>>>>>> origin/main

Hereâ€™s what this means:

<<<<<<< HEAD is your local version
======= is the separator
>>>>>>> origin/main is the version you pulled from GitHub.

In other words:

Anything between <<<<<<< HEAD and the ======= separator are your current changes.
Anything between the ======= and >>>>>>> origin/main is whatâ€™s on the Github version.

Step 3: Choose What to Keep
Now itâ€™s time to decide what version is correct.
You could:

Keep one
Combine them
Rewrite it entirely

Just make sure to delete the conflict markers (<<<<<<<, =======, >>>>>>>) when youâ€™ve decided what youâ€™d like to do.
Step 4: mark the conflict as resolved, commit and push
Once youâ€™ve fixed the file, you need to tell Git itâ€™s ready. We do this by saving our changes to the conflict file, then committing our changes and pushing the corrected file Github.
For our analysis.qmd conflict, for example, weâ€™d do the following:

Stage our resolved conflict file:
git add analysis.qmd
Commit our changes, noting the merge conflict in the commit message:
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflict in analysis.qmd"
Push the change to Github, so our team can see the resolution:
git push

ğŸ‰ Thatâ€™s it â€” youâ€™ve handled a merge conflict like a pro.

title: 18Â  Working with feature branches
section: 18.4 Step 3: push the new branch to GitHub
text:
18.4 Step 3: push the new branch to GitHub
Once youâ€™ve committed some changes on your branch, youâ€™ll probably want to back up your work by pushing it to Github.
The syntax to add a new branch to your repo is just like when we added our main branch during our initial project setup:
git push -u origin branch-name
This command does two things:

Creates the new branch on the GitHub project.
Links your local branch to it.

So if you wanted to add your new add-plot-experiment branch, for example, youâ€™d type and run:
git push -u origin add-plot-experiment
Terminal would show a response like:

To github.com:username/my-git-quarto-project.git [new branch] add-plot-experiment -> add-plot-experiment branch â€˜add-plot-experimentâ€™ set up to track â€˜origin/add-plot-experimentâ€™.*

If you go to your Github repo page, youâ€™ll now see the branch listed in your GitHub repo.



Github will display new feature branches in your repository

title: 19Â  Pull requests
section: 19.2 Step 1: Create a Branch and push to Github
text:
19.2 Step 1: Create a Branch and push to Github
First, make sure youâ€™re on a new branch (just like we did in Working with Feature Branches)

Create a new feature branch by running:
git checkout -b improve-plot
Make some edits to your plot file (e.g., tweak a plot or add some new text)
Stage and commit the changes:
git add filename.qmd 
git commit -m "Improve plot aesthetics"
Push the branch to GitHub:
git push -u origin improve-plot

title: 18Â  Pull requests
section: 18.3 Step 2: Open a Pull Request (PR) on GitHub
text:
18.3 Step 2: Open a Pull Request (PR) on GitHub
Once your branch is on GitHub, youâ€™ll see a banner like:



Github repo Pull Request banner


Click the blue â€œCompare & pull requestâ€ button!

Tip: You can also find this button under the â€œPull requestsâ€ tab at the top.

On the Open a pull request page, do the following:

Review whatâ€™s changing: underneath the form at the top of the page, Github will show you a list of commits and the files on the feature branch that are different than the main branch. These are the changes you will be merging into the main project. Before making the PR, youâ€™ll want to make sure that all the changes showing are intentional and ready to merge.
Add a title description: After confirming your changes are ready to merge, add a title to the PR and description with more details about what youâ€™re changing. The description and title should let others on your team know exactly what the changes are that they will be reviewing. See an example below.


Note: Github has added a lot of features to help pre-fill out the title based on what it thinks your PR is. Sometimes itâ€™s accurate, sometimes itâ€™s not so always double-check.


Click the Create pull request button.

Now others (or future you) can review the change.



Pull request form




18.3.1 ğŸ‘€ Step 3: Review and Discuss
If youâ€™re collaborating, your teammates can:

Leave comments on specific lines
Ask questions or suggest edits
Approve or request changes

Even if youâ€™re working alone, reviewing your changes with â€œfresh eyesâ€ before merging can help you catch mistakes.



18.3.2 âœ… Step 4: Merge the Pull Request
Once everything looks good, click Merge pull request â†’ Confirm merge
GitHub combines the branch into main.
Now go back to your project in R Studio, and run:
git checkout main
Now that youâ€™re back on your main branch, you will also need to â€œpull downâ€ the changes you made to your plot and merged into your main branch with your PR.
To pull the PR changes, run:
git pull
Now when you navigate to your 01-plot.qmd file, you should see your plot improvements.

18.3.2.1 ğŸ§¹ Cleanup old branches
Since we have merged our feature branch, letâ€™s remember to keep our repository clean by deleting the local and remote versions.
First, weâ€™ll delete the branch locally, by running:
`git branch -d improve-plot`
Next, weâ€™ll delete the remote branch on Github, by running:
`git push origin --delete improve-plot`




18.3.3 ğŸ’¡ Remember: Keep your main branch up to date
After merging a PR (especially someone elseâ€™s), sync your local main branch:
git checkout main git pull
Now you have all the latest changes from GitHub.

title: 19Â  Pull requests
section: 19.3 Step 2: Open pull request (PR) on GitHub
text:
19.3 Step 2: Open pull request (PR) on GitHub
Instead of merging our changes from the command line like we did in the last chapter, weâ€™re going to handle the merging process in Github so we can take advantage of some of the nice features it offers for code reviews.
Once your branch is on GitHub, youâ€™ll see a banner like



Github repo Pull Request banner


To begin the pull request process:

Click the blue â€œCompare & pull requestâ€ button! (Tip: The banner sometimes will not show up when there isnâ€™t a new commit on the branch. You can also find this button under the â€œPull requestsâ€ tab at the top.)

On the Open a pull request page, do the following:

Review whatâ€™s changing: underneath the form at the top of the page, Github will show you a list of commits and the files on the feature branch that are different than the main branch. These are the changes you will be merging into the main project. Before making the PR, youâ€™ll want to make sure that all the changes showing are intentional and ready to merge.
Add a title description: After confirming your changes are ready to merge, add a title to the PR and description with more details about what youâ€™re changing. The description and title should let others on your team know exactly what the changes are that they will be reviewing. See an example below.

Note: Github has added a lot of features to help pre-fill out the title based on what it thinks your PR is. Sometimes itâ€™s accurate, sometimes itâ€™s not so always double-check.

Click the Create pull request button.

Now others (or future you) can review the change.



Pull request form



19.3.1 Step 3: review and discuss changes
If youâ€™re collaborating, your teammates can:

Leave comments on specific lines
Ask questions or suggest edits
Approve or request changes

Even if youâ€™re working alone, reviewing your changes with â€œfresh eyesâ€ before merging can help you catch mistakes.
Sometimes your collaborators will suggest changes to files or code before â€œapprovingâ€ the code to be merged. During the pull review process, youâ€™ll discuss your changes and make sure everyone is on board for your code changes before incorporating them into the main project. This process is called a code review in the programming world and itâ€™s an important part of the development process, especially for user-facing, live projects.



19.3.2 Step 4: Merge the Pull Request
Once everything looks good, you can proceed to merging your branch.
To merge in your branch:

Click dropdown icon next to Merge pull request and make sure Create a merge commit is selected.
Click Merge pull request.
If prompted, type a commit message, or accept the default message in the description box.
Click Confirm merge. GitHub will combine the branch into main.
Now go back to your terminal tab in your RStudio project, and run:
git checkout main

Now that youâ€™re back on your main branch, you will also need to â€œpull downâ€ the changes you made to your plot and merged into your main branch with your PR.
Pull the merged PR changes:

Make sure youâ€™re on your main by running git branch. If you arenâ€™t, run the following to get to there:
git checkout main
Once youâ€™ve confirmed youâ€™re on main, pull your changes by running:
git pull

Now when you navigate to your 01-plot.qmd file, you should see your plot improvements.

title: 19Â  Pull requests
text:
19.4 Cleanup old branches
Since we have merged our feature branch, letâ€™s remember to keep our repository clean by deleting the local and remote versions of our merged branches.

First, weâ€™ll delete the branch locally, by running:
git branch -d improve-plot
Next, weâ€™ll delete the remote branch on Github, by running:
git push origin --delete improve-plot

title: 19Â  Pull requests
section: 19.5 Remember: Keep your main branch up to date
text:
19.5 Remember: Keep your main branch up to date
After merging a PR (especially someone elseâ€™s), sync your local main branch by doing the following in your terminal.

First, navigate to the main branch by running:
git checkout main
Then, pull the most recent changes:
git pull

Now you have all the latest changes from GitHub.

title: 1Â  Welcome
section: Conventions and styles in this book
text:
Conventions and styles in this book
We hold the deep belief that â€œall ships rise with the tideâ€ when members of the data journalism community learn together, and this book seeks to add to that mission. Weâ€™ve written this textbook in the first-person plural to foster a sense of collaboration and shared learning between the reader and the authors. By using pronouns like â€œweâ€ and â€œour,â€ our guide invites students into a learning journey that feels supportive and inclusive, rather than distant or instructional. It reflects the idea that learning to code is not a solitary task, but a process that many people engage in together. Our aim for this guide is to help beginners feel less intimidated, encouraging them to see mistakes and discoveries as part of a shared experience, not personal failures.
We will try to be consistent in the way we write documentation and lessons, but we are human and sometimes we break our own rules. In general, keep the following in mind:

Things to do
Things to DO are in ordered lists:

Do this thing.
Then do this thing.

Explanations are usually in text, like this very paragraph.
Sometimes details will be explained in lists:

This is the first thing I want you to know.
This is the second. You donâ€™t have to DO these things, just know about them.



Code blocks
This book often runs the code that is shown, so youâ€™ll see the code and the result of that code below it.

1 + 1

[1] 2



1.0.0.1 Copying code blocks
When you see code in the instructions, you can roll your cursor over the right-corner and click on the copy icon to copy the code clock content to your clipboard.

You can then paste the code inside your coding program chunk.
That said, typing code yourself has many, many benefits. You learn better when you type yourself, make mistakes and have to fix them. We encourage you to always type short code snippets. Leave the copying to long ones.


1.0.0.2 Hidden code
Sometimes we want to include code in the book but not display it so you can try the to write the code yourself first. When we do this, it will look like this:


Click here to show the code
1 + 1


[1] 2


If you click on the triangle or the words that follow, youâ€™ll reveal the code. Click again to hide it.


1.0.0.3 Annotated code
Sometimes when we are explaining code it is helpful to match lines of code to the explanation about them, which we do through annotated code.

1mtcars |>
2  head()


1

First we take the Motor Trend Car Road Tests data set AND THEN â€¦

2

We pipe into the head() command, which gives us the â€œtopâ€ of the data.




                   mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb
Mazda RX4         21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4
Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4
Datsun 710        22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1
Hornet 4 Drive    21.4   6  258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44  1  0    3    1
Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8  360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02  0  0    3    2
Valiant           18.1   6  225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22  1  0    3    1


When there are annotations like this you have to be careful if you are copying code from the book. Either copy it one line at a time or use the copy icon noted above.


1.0.0.4 Fenced code
Sometimes we need to show code chunk options that are added, like when explaining how to name chunks. In those cases, you may see the code chunk with all the tick marks, etc. like this:

```{r block-named}
1 + 1
```

[1] 2


or

```{r}
#| label: block-named-yaml

1 + 1
```

[1] 2


You can still copy/paste these blocks, but youâ€™ll get the entire code block, not just the contents.



Notes, some important
We will use information callouts to set off a less important aside:






Markdown was developed by JOHN GRUBER, as outlined on his Daring Fireball blog.



But sometimes those asides are important. We usually indicate that by using:






Important



You really should learn how to use Markdown as you will use it the whole semester, and hopefully for the rest of your life.


Or we may use a caution callout:






Caution



Not learning Markdown may result in you earning less than stellar grades.


Time to enter the Matrix, Neo.



Fun fact: the original design for the green â€œdigital rainâ€ animation used in the Matrix was based on scans of the creatorâ€™s wifeâ€™s Japanese cookbook.



Next up:
Weâ€™ll learn how to move around inside your computer using simple commands. Whenever youâ€™re ready, proceed to the next chapter.

title: 6Â  Troubleshooting
text:
6.3 Change Mac shell to bash
Mac Catalina changes the default shell program from Bash to zsh. While zsh is a great shell, we are using Bash in this class for consistency.

Open a Terminal
Copy or Type and run this command:
chsh -s /bin/bash
You will be asked to enter your computer password. YOU WONâ€™T SEE KEYSTROKES AS YOU TYPE in your password. Just type it in anyway and hit Return. If you flub the password, youâ€™ll have to enter the above command again.
If you donâ€™t get an error, close your terminal and reopen it and it should say â€œbashâ€ at the top.

Alternative method:
If for some reason that doesnâ€™t work, there is this way, too:

Choose Apple menu ï£¿ > System Settings, then click Users & Groups.
Click the lock, then enter your account name and password.
Control-click your user name in the list of users on the left, then choose Advanced Options.
Choose a shell from the â€Login shellâ€ menu, then click OK to save the changes.



Default to bash


Click OK and close the System Preferences window.
Close any Terminal windows you have open and restart them.

title: 14Â  Updating files
text:
14.3 Stage Change (git add...)
Now that you know Git sees the change, you need to tell Git, â€œHey, save this file in the next snapshot.â€
Like with our initial commit, youâ€™ll prep your files by adding â€” or staging â€” them for your next commit.
This time around, weâ€™re going to be a bit more surgical with the files we commit by only adding the individual file rather than using the . to add all files.
To stage only your index file:

Run the following:
git add 01-index.qmd
Check your Git status again by running:
git status

You should see your 01-index.qmd file in green, along with following message:
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git restore --staged <file>..." to unstage)
  modified:   01-index.qmd`
ğŸ‰ Great! Your changed file is now staged and ready to commit.

git setup

Use the default settings for everything else.
You should now be able to find the program Git Bash from your Windows Start menu. Go ahead and launch it.

text:
If you want, you can change the terminalâ€™s color theme to make it more comfortable to look at by doing the following:

macOSWindows

title: 7Â  Quick reference
text: 7.1 Terminology

title: 7Â  Quick reference
text:
ğŸ““ Term
ğŸ“– What It Means




Command line
The interface where you type and run text commands


Shell
The program that interprets your commands and runs them (e.g.Â bash, zsh)


Terminal
The user interface that displays the shell and lets you interact with it. Examples: Terminal (Mac), Git Bash (Windows)


Directory (Folder)
A container for files


Path
The location of a file or folder


Flag
Extra option for a command

text:
7.2 Common commands

title: 6Â  Troubleshooting
text:
6.1 Common pitfalls and errors
In this final chapter, letâ€™s touch quickly on navigating common issues you might run into using the terminal.
Hereâ€™s a quick rundown of the most common problems and errors youâ€™ll run into using the command line. Even experienced developers run into these issues, so learning what they mean will go a long way when troubleshooting.
For more common issues and how to fix them, see the Common errors table in the Glossary at the end of this guide.

title: 6Â  Troubleshooting
text:
Command not found? You might have a typo or the program isnâ€™t installed.
No such file or directory? You might be trying to access a file/path that doesnâ€™t exist. Check that the file exists and that you spelled it correctly. You could also not be in the directory you think you are â€” try running pwd or ls to check your location, then use the cd to navigate where you should be if needed.
Permission denied?
You tried to do something you donâ€™t have permission to do. Check your file/repo permissions.
Syntax error
You typed a command in a way the shell doesnâ€™t understand. Check that your syntax is correct and error-free.
Stuck in a weird app inside Terminal?
Try pressing Ctrl + C or Ctrl + D to exit. (You may need to checkout â€œHow to get out of Vimâ€ below)

title: 6Â  Troubleshooting
section: 6.2 How to Get Out of Vim
text:
6.2 How to Get Out of Vim
Every new command line user shares one panic-inducing experience at one point or another: accidentally opening Vim and not knowing how to get out of it.
In this section, weâ€™ll briefly walk you through what Vim is and how to exit it so you donâ€™t panic when this (inevitably) happens to you.
What is Vim?
Vim is a text editor built into most Unix systems, including macOS and Linux. Itâ€™s used by developers to edit code and configuration files, but it works very differently from regular text editors.
If you accidentally open something in Vim (for example, by running git commit without a message), it might look like youâ€™re stuck. But donâ€™t worry â€” hereâ€™s how to exit safely.
How to Exit Vim
If you donâ€™t want to save any changes (most common):

Press Esc - to make sure youâ€™re not in input mode.
Type :q! - to â€œquit and ignore changesâ€.
Hit Enter / return - to exit.

If You do want to save changes (less common):

Press Esc
Type :wq (to â€œwrite and quitâ€).
Press Enter / return

title: 6Â  Troubleshooting
text:
6.3 Change Mac shell to bash
Mac Catalina changes the default shell program from Bash to zsh. While zsh is a great shell, we are using Bash in this class for consistency.

Open a Terminal
Copy or Type and run this command:
chsh -s /bin/bash
You will be asked to enter your computer password. YOU WONâ€™T SEE KEYSTROKES AS YOU TYPE in your password. Just type it in anyway and hit Return. If you flub the password, youâ€™ll have to enter the above command again.
If you donâ€™t get an error, close your terminal and reopen it and it should say â€œbashâ€ at the top.

Alternative method:
If for some reason that doesnâ€™t work, there is this way, too:

Choose Apple menu ï£¿ > System Settings, then click Users & Groups.
Click the lock, then enter your account name and password.
Control-click your user name in the list of users on the left, then choose Advanced Options.
Choose a shell from the â€Login shellâ€ menu, then click OK to save the changes.



Default to bash


Click OK and close the System Preferences window.
Close any Terminal windows you have open and restart them.

title: 8Â  Change your terminalâ€™s color
text:
If you want, you can change the terminalâ€™s color theme to make it more comfortable to look at by doing the following:

macOSWindows



For Macs, click â€œTerminalâ€ in the App Menu at the very top of your screen (next to the Apple menu ï£¿) .
Select Settings in the dropdown menu.
Select Profiles in the tabs at the top of the window.
Select the theme youâ€™d like to use from the options on the left (â€œProâ€ is a good option for dark mode)
Click the Default button at the end of bottom of the theme options to set your preferred theme.
Youâ€™ll need to quit and relaunch terminal to see the new theme.




Mac Terminal Profile themes





For Windows, right-click the title bar at the top of your Git Bash window (where it says â€œMINGW64â€ or â€œGit Bashâ€).
Select Properties (it may be Options on your machine)
In the popup window, select the Colors tab.
Adjust the colors as needed by selecting the radio button for what you want to change (e.g., Screen Text) and clicking on a color box or entering RGB values
Click OK or Apply to save.

title: 20Â  Troubleshooting
text:
Common scenarios and fixes
Even experienced developers forget a command or hit a weird error sometimes. You will mess up Git at some point. Thatâ€™s part of the learning process!
Hereâ€™s how to recover from common problems and feel less stuck.

title: 20Â  Troubleshooting
text:
â€œI made a change I donâ€™t want anymoreâ€
Scenario 1: you changed a file but havenâ€™t committed it yet.
Run:
git restore filename.qmd
This resets the file to how it was in your last commit.
Scenario 2: you changed a file and already staged it (git add <filename>)
First, unstage it by running:
git restore --staged filename.qmd
Then run:
git restore filename.qmd


â€œI committed the wrong thingâ€
You can undo the most recent commit (without losing your changes):
git reset --soft HEAD~1
Now your changes are back in the staging area. Fix what you need, and recommit.
If you want to undo the commit and all your changes:
git reset --hard HEAD~1
âš ï¸ Warning: Using --hard will delete your work â€” only use this if youâ€™re really sure!


â€œI forgot to add a file before committingâ€
If you made a commit but forgot a file you meant to include:
Step 1: Stage the missing file:
git add missed_file.qmd
Step 2: Amend your last commit:
git commit --amend
This opens the Terminalâ€™s default text editor, Vim, so you can update the message or leave it the same. Git will include the new file in the same commit.
After editing your message in Vim:

Press Esc to make sure youâ€™re not in insert mode.
Type :wq (stands for write and quit).
Press Enter / returnto save you changes and exit Vim.



â€œI canâ€™t push because â€˜tip of your current branch is behindâ€™â€
This means someone else pushed changes to GitHub before you.
To fix it:
git pull --rebase
This fetches the new work and replays your changes on top of it. If thereâ€™s a conflict, Git will pause and ask you to resolve it. Once done, run:
git add . git rebase --continue
Then push again:
git push
